headline: Panti Bliss, Ireland’s Queen of Drag, Expands Her Kingdom
text: Ireland became the first country in the world to legalize same-sex marriage by popular vote in 2015, thanks in part to the advocacy of a drag queen called Panti Bliss.

headline: Daily Report: Google Would Like You to Meet Its Gadgets
text: We present to you Google, the Silicon Valley gadget company.

headline: 15 Years Ago: The Times Establishes a Bureau in Kabul
text: In the aftermath of the American-led invasion of Afghanistan, I was sent to manage telecommunications and logistics for The Times — and I recorded what I saw with a small digital camera.

headline: For Transgender Youths in New York, It Would Be a Health Care Milestone
text: ALBANY — The New York State Health Department has signaled that it intends to allow transgender youths to receive Medicaid coverage for hormones that forestall puberty, wiping away prohibitions that have been criticized by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender groups.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Chanel and Kenzo
text: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Paris on Tuesday.

headline: Fashion That Doesn’t Let You Use Your Hands
text: Hands are out for spring/summer 2017. In fact, they’re not out, which is really my point. They’re out of fashion, which means designers have largely concealed them inside a sleeve, the hem hanging anywhere between the third knuckle and several inches below the fingertips.

headline: The Neighborhood Bookstore’s Unlikely Ally? The Internet
text: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. — When Peter Makin opened Brilliant Books five years ago, he quickly realized his business wouldn’t survive in this remote locale if his only customers were local buyers.

headline: How to Get Kenzo’s All-Red Disco Beauty Look
text: For Kenzo’s spring/summer 2017 show, the designers Carol Lim and Humberto Leon channeled the illustrator Antonio Lopez’s muses — Pat Cleveland, Grace Jones, Donna Jordan and Jerry Hall — in Studio 54. And the all-red makeup look followed suit, pulling “inspiration from the ’70s or ’80s and making it modern,” said the makeup artist Lynsey Alexander. “It’s definitely not retro.”

headline: Maria Sharapova Claims Victory and Goes on the Offensive
text: With her doping suspension reduced by an appeals court, Maria Sharapova will be allowed to return to professional tennis in time for next year’s French Open. The top officials for the sport’s global governing body are unlikely to be there cheering for her.

headline: What’s the Longest Humans Can Live? 115 Years, New Study Says
text: On Aug. 4, 1997, Jeanne Calment passed away in a nursing home in France. The Reaper comes for us all, of course, but he was in no hurry for Mrs. Calment. She died at age 122, setting a record for human longevity.

headline: How to Get That Elevated Tracksuit Look
text: The sporty tracksuit look is peaking in a high-style way. (Read: This is not an athleisure trend.) Here’s how to wear it.

headline: Christine, a Pop Star Who Sings With Her Muscles
text: For Héloïse Letissier, Christine is a disguise, a truth serum, a state of mind. The French pop singer-songwriter behind Christine and the Queens, Ms. Letissier created her alter ego as a way, as she recently explained, “to feel good in my own skin.”

headline: Doing Good at Bloomingdale’s: Donald Robertson Signs Sweatshirts to Aid Breast Cancer Research.
text: On Saturday, kick off Breast Cancer Awareness Month with a Pure Yoga class ($10) at Bloomingdale’s 59th Street at 8:30 a.m., before the store opens. Then at noon, the illustrator Donald Robertson will be signing sweatshirts he designed for the store’s October Pink campaign ($40), with $15 from each sale benefiting the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. … That same day, head to the #GiltLife House, the flash-sale site’s pop-up experience, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., to enjoy culinary demonstrations by the James Beard Award-winning chef Chris Fischer and check out fall fashions, like a Marc Jacobs mini suede cross-body ($456), that are available to shop during October. At 4 Centre Market Place. Tickets ($5 for Gilt members) are available at gilt.com. On Sunday, from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., Kit and Ace, will host a shopping event to celebrate the debut of Love Stories TV, an online platform for wedding videos. The site’s founder, Rachel Jo Silver, will be on hand to help brides-to-be pick honeymoon travel pieces like an easy silk shirtdress ($248). At 255 Elizabeth Street. … Throughout October, Loeffler Randall is inviting customers to shop the showroom at its new SoHo headquarters, where you’ll find pretty fall bits like a flap bucket bag ($350) and silver tassel oxfords ($395). At 588 Broadway, Suite 1203. To book an appointment, visit www.LoefflerRandall.com.

headline: Randi Malkin Steinberger’s “No Circus” Photos
text: The photographer’s new book features the vivid tents that mark Los Angeles homes being gassed for termite infestations.

headline: A Bizarre, Colorful California Rite of Passage, in Photos
text: In the 1960s, Ed Ruscha, the poet laureate of the weird contours of Los Angeles, began taking pictures of the city’s gas stations, apartment complexes and parking lots — the mostly banal things one would encounter while going for a drive — and compiling them into inexpensively produced booklets. He eventually formed not only a taxonomy of Southern California’s architectural vernacular — but its languorous temperament, too, and the ways of living people (who rarely figured in the pictures) choose for themselves.

headline: Federal Warning on Possible Florida Strike by Hurricane Matthew
text: Rick Knabb, director of the National Hurricane Center, warns Floridians that Hurricane Matthew could hit as a Category 4 storm late Thursday.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker, Molly Shannon and Jerry Seinfeld at HBO’s Premiere of ‘Divorce’
text: The erstwhile Carrie Bradshaw celebrates her new show: a dark comedy about middle-age suburbanites and their crumbling marriage.

headline: On Epic Spawning Migration, Eels May Travel at Their Own Pace
text: Every year, when the autumn chill sets in, eels start to transform. Their skins thicken, donning a coat of mucus and changing from a muddied yellow to a gunmetal silver. Their stomachs shrivel and turn white. Their eyes expand, so they can see better in the dark. On moonless, stormy nights, when the rivers flow fast, they travel downstream until they reach the sea. Then, they disappear.

headline: How Much Is It Worth to Hold Your Newborn? $40, Apparently
text: After holding his newborn son for the first time at a Utah hospital last month, a man found a strange charge on his bill: $39.35.

headline: Lavish, Vintage-Inspired Emeralds
text: Captivating gems that give the green light.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker and Ta-Nehisi Coates, on New Literary Paths
text: Having conquered their respective fields, the actress Sarah Jessica Parker and the journalist Ta-Nehisi Coates are heading into the literary unknown.

headline: Homeopathic Teething Gels May Pose Risks
text: Parents should throw away any homeopathic teething tablets and gels they may be using, since they may pose a risk to infants and children, the Food and Drug Administration is warning.

headline: Ava DuVernay on Modern Slavery in America
text: Ava DuVernay’s new documentary, “13th,” opened the New York Film Festival last week with a thunderclap, relating the damning story of how, in the age of mass incarceration, prisons have largely become plantations, disproportionately warehousing and exploiting African-American men. The title of the film, which reaches theaters and Netflix on Friday, refers to the 13th Amendment to the Constitution abolishing slavery except as punishment for a crime, a crucial loophole that, in Ms. DuVernay’s forceful telling, has been used for political gain and profit.

headline: F.B.I. Criminal Complaint Against Harold Martin, N.S.A. Contractor
text: The F.B.I. secretly arrested Harold T. Martin III, an N.S.A. contractor, and is investigating whether he stole and disclosed highly classified information.

headline: Why Wouldn’t Tiffany Trump Speak for Herself?
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: An Alarming 10% Rise in Traffic Deaths in the First Half of 2016
text: Traffic deaths in the United States rose 10.4 percent in the first half of this year compared with the same period in 2015, maintaining a steady climb.

headline: And the Winner Is …? Using Statistics to Predict the 2016 Presidential Election
text: Overview

headline: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company, Passes an In-Flight Escape Test
text: Blue Origin, the rocket company started by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the billionaire chief executive of Amazon, successfully separated a crew capsule from a rocket after it had lifted off on Wednesday, an important step toward Blue Origin’s goal of carrying tourists into space.

headline: The Editorialists Have Spoken; Will Voters Listen?
text: The Atlantic magazine has made only two presidential endorsements in its 159-year history: one for Abraham Lincoln in 1860 and one for Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.

headline: Gilbert Cruz: How The Times Covers Television
text: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

headline: To Enhance Scoring, N.H.L. Looks to Shrink the Goalie
text: BUFFALO — At 6 feet 5 inches and 235 pounds, Buffalo Sabres goaltender Robin Lehner is big even by N.H.L. standards, able to block much of the net by using his bulk.

headline: Hashtags, Polls and Putin: Aftermath of the Vice-Presidential Debate
text: The vice-presidential debate may be in the books, but the post-debate spin goes on.

headline: Rocket Test: A Step Toward Space Tourism
text: Blue Origin, a rocket company owned by Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, successfully launched and landed a capsule and booster, putting the company closer to its goal of carrying tourists into space.

headline: A Call for Difficult Conversations, Not Censorship
text: To the Editor:

headline: Elliott’s Demands on Samsung Might Have Staying Power
text: The hedge fund Elliott Management’s attack on Samsung Electronics of South Korea may have staying power. Elliott wants the Samsung to restructure, pay a $27 billion special dividend, pledge to return at least 75 percent of free cash flow to investors and agree to appoint some independent directors.

headline: Yahoo Said to Have Aided U.S. Email Surveillance by Adapting Spam Filter
text: A system intended to scan emails for child pornography and spam helped Yahoo satisfy a secret court order requiring it to search for messages containing a computer “signature” tied to the communications of a state-sponsored terrorist organization, several people familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Review: In ‘The Girl on the Train,’ a Boozy Emily Blunt Never Winks
text: “The Girl on the Train” is a preposterous movie but not an unenjoyable one. If that sounds like faint praise, well, it is and it isn’t. There’s always something to be said for an entertainment that sustains its nuttiness all the way to its twisty finish. This one may not make much sense, but — like a demented old film noir or a Shonda Rhimes show at its crazed best — “Girl” doesn’t falter in its absurdity or commitment to its own seriousness. It never winks. You may laugh (as the audience I saw it with did, on and off), but there’s genuine pleasure in that mirth.

headline: In Visceral Ads for Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump Does All the Talking
text: The ads are stark: Adolescent girls assessing themselves before a mirror or a cellphone camera, stroking their hair, straightening their clothes and seeking personal reassurance about their appearance. The strained self-assessment is then met with a jarring interruption.

headline: Kate Middleton’s Tour of Canada: A Designer Scorecard
text: The masses have long been intrigued by royals’ fashion choices, and the royals, in turn, have used their sartorial presentation to establish and manage their reputations in the public eye. In a letter to one of her sons, Queen Victoria, whom a historian once called “the first media monarch,” wrote that what you wear gives “the one outward sign from which people in general can and often do judge upon the inward state of mind and feeling of a person; for this they all see, while the other they cannot.”

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Dash Mihok Reads ‘A Path to Fatherhood, With (Shared) Morning Sickness’
text: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actor Dash Mihok (“Ray Donovan,” “I Am Legend”) reads the essay “A Path to Fatherhood, With (Shared) Morning Sickness,” about a man whose wife conceives just before he begins chemotherapy for metastatic cancer.

headline: From Ralph Nader: Don’t Blame Third Parties
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Did the Running Mates Do?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three’s a Trend: The Return of the Power Suit
text: Suits with big shoulders, a staple of the ’80s career woman’s wardrobe, made a comeback this season. The trend first came on strong at the Jil Sander show in Milan, where Rodolfo Paglialunga added extra-large shoulder pads to almost every look. Over in Paris, Céline’s classic three-button suit, in a neutral taupe, was tailored for the perfect oversize fit. And Balenciaga — where Demna Gvasalia played with boxy silhouettes last season, too — showed an army of oversize shoulders, too, as in this pinstriped skirt suit paired with a bright pink shirt.

headline: The Surprising Defeat of Colombia’s Peace Plan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘L’Italiana in Algeri,’ a Comedy With Coloratura and Pasta
text: There came a point during Tuesday’s performance of Rossini’s “L’Italiana in Algeri” at the Metropolitan Opera when I vowed I would stop laughing at the sophomoric spectacle in front of me.

headline: Southwest Flight Evacuated After Samsung Phone Catches Fire, Airline Says
text: A Southwest Airlines flight scheduled to leave Louisville, Ky., on Wednesday morning was evacuated on the runway after a passenger’s Samsung cellphone caught fire, passengers and the airline said.

headline: Recognizing Boarding Schools’ Psychic Toll in China
text: BEIJING — The emotional disintegration of a 17-month-old boy named John as he sought and failed to find comfort from caregivers in a British boarding nursery, captured in a 1969 documentary film, deeply distressed the Chinese women at a seminar last week on early childhood separation.

headline: Debate Segment on Race and Policing Leaves Activists Underwhelmed
text: For 10 minutes at their debate on Tuesday, the Republican and Democratic vice-presidential nominees argued about race and policing, offering their opinions on what might improve the relationship between police officers and members of minority groups across the country.

headline: Developer That ‘Cracked the Code’ on Modular Building Exits the Business
text: Five years after announcing that it had “cracked the code” on modular building technology and would open a factory in Brooklyn to construct modules, the developer Forest City Ratner is getting out of the prefab construction business.

headline: Want to Help Pay for a Child’s College? Grab a Gift Card
text: Parents are often reluctant to solicit gifts for their children’s college funds, even though they might prefer a gift of cash to another stuffed animal. But friends and relatives will soon have an option to contribute to a 529 saving account without being asked.

headline: An Artist’s Eye to the Sky, Transformed at MoMA PS1
text: The three-year renovation of James Turrell’s beloved skyspace at MoMA PS1 might have tried even the patience of the Quakers who inspired it.

headline: Review: When Reading Tana French’s Ingenious New Novel, Assume Nothing
text: Tana French, the superb Irish novelist who happens to write avidly about crime, used to link her books by having a minor character in one become the beleaguered protagonist of the next. Since the books all involved the Dublin Murder Squad, the beleaguered part came easily. But in her sixth novel, “The Trespasser,” she breaks that pattern to reunite the same pair of detectives who waded through “The Secret Place,” her fifth. That one took place at a swanky private school, a grating milieu where the girls’ teen language (“Um, duh?”) wasn’t easy for the detectives, Antoinette Conway and Stephen Moran, to take.

headline: Review: ‘Revolution Radio’ Finds Green Day Still Unsatisfied
text: The state of the world is just too much for Green Day on “Revolution Radio.” Violence, war, death and lies loom everywhere; a glimmer of love or truth, or simply a respite, is the most the band can hope for, and it’s far from enough. But the tumult and desperation ignite the music on “Revolution Radio.” It’s the group’s first batch of new songs since “Uno! Dos! Tré!,” the three-disc surfeit of more straightforward tunes released in 2012. Those songs were built around snappy catchphrases and brisk, punky riffs. Green Day’s new ones aren’t so easily summed up, but they can roar through their contradictions.

headline: Justices Seem Ready to Find Bias in Trial of Black Man on Texas Death Row
text: WASHINGTON — In a decidedly lopsided argument in a death penalty case at the Supreme Court on Wednesday, the only dispute among the justices was whether they should rule narrowly or broadly in favor of Duane Buck, a Texas death row inmate whose trial was marred by testimony that black men are more dangerous than others.

headline: Review: Maria Hassabi’s ‘Staged’ Might Have a Better Title as ‘Runway’
text: It’s no coincidence that “Plastic,” one of Maria Hassabi’s most successful ventures in her mission to place bodies in extreme states of slowness, occurred not in a theater but at the Museum of Modern Art last winter. Somehow, by placing her dancers in a landscape of stationary art and normal people moving at a normal pace, her work gained greater intensity.

headline: Can Women Be Trusted on Abortion? Two Men Weigh In
text: Well, that was painful. What with the cross talk, interruptions, insults, sneers and overly rehearsed zingers, the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday surely bewildered more voters than it enlightened. There was one area, though, in which both Senator Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence were crystal-clear and decidedly different: abortion rights.

headline: Stepping Over the Dead on a Migrant Boat
text: It began with blips on a radar screen, 12 miles off the Libyan coast. As the rescuers approached, they found overloaded wooden vessels and rafts that evoked scenes of the slave trade.

headline: New York Film Festival: Determined Women and Uncertainty in the World
text: As you watch television news reports of the European migrant crisis, your eyes may glaze over at the sight of so much suffering packaged into brief segments on a small screen. But Gianfranco Rosi’s documentary “Fire at Sea,” a high point of the 2016 New York Film Festival, makes it real, life-size and viscerally unnerving.

headline: Questions and Answers on Hurricane Matthew
text: John Schwartz, a New York Times reporter who covers climate change and the environment, is answering reader questions about the storm. John rode out his first hurricane, Carla, in his hometown, Galveston, Tex., at the age of 4. He has covered the aftermath of Katrina, as well as other storms for The Times.

headline: Richard J. Schwartz, Who Expanded Jonathan Logan’s Dress Empire, Dies at 77
text: Richard J. Schwartz, who at 25 took over the dressmaker Jonathan Logan from his father and built it into an even more successful enterprise, died on Monday in Upper Nyack, N.Y. He was 77.

headline: United States Criticizes Israel Over West Bank Settlement Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday castigated the Israeli government for approving plans to create a new Jewish settlement on the West Bank, three weeks after it signed a lucrative military aid package with the United States and just as President Obama was traveling to Jerusalem for the funeral of Shimon Peres.

headline: Mike Pence, N.S.A., Nobel Prize: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Vice-Presidential Debate Generates Fireworks, but Not Ratings
text: No Trump, no bump.

headline: Allen Roses, Who Upset Common Wisdom on Cause of Alzheimer’s, Dies at 73
text: Allen Roses, a maverick researcher whose team of scientists identified two genes that put healthy people over 65 at higher risk for Alzheimer’s disease, died on Friday in New York. He was 73.

headline: How Mom and Dad Met, With Ninjas
text: On a sunny Southern California day in the spring of 2015, a full house showed up to attend not a play, but a reading of a play: “Vietgone” by Qui Nguyen. It was the last day of the Pacific Playwrights Festival, hosted by the local South Coast Repertory theater. “Vietgone” was the final presentation, a two-and-a-half-hour piece about a complicated event: the Vietnam War.

headline: Donald Trump’s Slip in Polls Has G.O.P. Worried About Congress
text: Donald J. Trump’s support has plunged across the swing-state map over the last 10 days, wiping out his political recovery from September and threatening to undo weeks of Republican gains in the battle for control of Congress.

headline: Wild-Card Lineup Is Set for the Mets. Now Comes the Game.
text: The Mets tried to balance health and their opponent when they finalized their 25-man roster and starting lineup for Wednesday’s National League wild-card game against the San Francisco Giants.

headline: Marshall Islands Can’t Sue the World’s Nuclear Powers, U.N. Court Rules
text: PARIS — The United Nations’ highest court on Wednesday rejected a bid by the Marshall Islands to sue the world’s nuclear powers, saying the court did not have jurisdiction because there was no evidence of a legal dispute that it could adjudicate.

headline: N.J. Transit Changes Rules for Trains Arriving at Hoboken Station
text: In the wake of the fatal train crash in Hoboken last week, New Jersey Transit ordered on Wednesday that a second crew member must stand watch as the engineer pulls a train into that busy terminal.

headline: We’re All a Little Biased, Even if We Don’t Know It
text: One of the newest chew toys in the presidential campaign is “implicit bias,” a term Mike Pence repeatedly took exception to in the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday.

headline: Sometimes It Pays to Sit
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Phyllis Creore, ‘Canteen Girl’ on Wartime Radio, Dies at 100
text: Sometimes Tokyo Rose was the best thing on the radio — if you were an American serviceman overseas during World War II. You put up with her demoralizing pro-Japanese propaganda to hear the popular music. But sometimes things were infinitely better. For 15 minutes on Fridays on the shortwave, there was Canteen Girl.

headline: Rod Temperton, Who Wrote ‘Thriller’ for Michael Jackson and ‘Boogie Nights,’ Dies
text: Rod Temperton, who wrote the 1970s disco classic “Boogie Nights” and went on to compose some of Michael Jackson’s biggest hits, including “Rock With You” and “Thriller,” died last week. His family gave his age as 66, though many sources indicate he was 68.

headline: Gary Johnson Equates Syria Deaths Caused by Assad and West
text: Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party presidential nominee, drew a parallel on Wednesday between the Syrian government’s targeting of noncombatants in that nation’s civil war and the accidental bombing of civilians by United States-backed forces.

headline: Ex-Ally of Christie Hews to Story as Bridge Case Testimony Ends
text: NEWARK — David Wildstein is a serial prankster and a manipulative liar. He once stole a United States senator’s jacket to make him squirm during a debate. He boasted, falsely, of suppressing votes by sending black and Democratic voters on a bus trip to Atlantic City.

headline: Call Centers in India Posed as I.R.S. to Cheat U.S. Taxpayers, Authorities Say
text: NEW DELHI — The call centers outside Mumbai looked like many others that have sprung up across India in recent decades. But investigators say the hundreds of people who worked at the nine centers had an unusual assignment: posing as Internal Revenue Service officers and demanding money from American taxpayers.

headline: Bigger Museum Will Give Lady Liberty’s Crowds More to Do Than Snap Selfies
text: It is time for a backyard construction project on an island with a resident population of one and a transient population of 4.3 million.

headline: New York State to Eliminate Cash Option for Paying Tolls
text: For motorists in New York, the only things that may rival death and taxes as certainties are traffic and tolls — the latter of which, for the better part of the last 80 years, have been collected by hand.

headline: Israel Halts Yacht Trying to Break Its Blockade of Gaza Strip
text: JERUSALEM — Their chances of reaching the shores of Gaza were never high: Thirteen women on a yacht hoping to breach the years-old sea blockade of the Hamas-run Palestinian coastal territory enforced by the Israeli Navy.

headline: With Youth in Place, the Yankees Look Ahead
text: On the day the Mets made a second straight playoff appearance, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman voiced optimism about the future of a franchise that has appeared in one postseason game in four years.

headline: Dusty Baker Is Tied to His Opponents, but Backing Down From None of Them
text: WASHINGTON — Dusty Baker had an out-of-town baseball friend in his office at Nationals Park last week. It happens a lot around here.

headline: Oil Glut? Here Comes Some More!
text: HOUSTON — Global oil markets are flooded with cheap crude, and concerns about climate change are growing louder. The last thing the world seems to be craving is the discovery of new large oil and natural gas fields.

headline: A New Voice for a Complicated World
text: By any measure, António Guterres of Portugal is an excellent choice to replace Ban Ki-moon of South Korea as the next United Nations secretary general. He has experience, energy and diplomatic finesse, all of which he’ll need to lead the United Nations as it confronts regional wars, rising tensions between Russia and the West, China’s aggressive posture in Asia and the refugee crisis in the Middle East and Europe.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker, Molly Shannon and Jerry Seinfeld at HBO’s Premiere of ‘Divorce’
text: There was Sarah Jessica Parker (“Sex and the City”) huddling with Matthew Broderick (“Election”), as guests tucked into plates of pumpkin agnolotti by Mario Batali (Babbo) and bantered about the latest Clinton White House run.

headline: A ‘Sad Case’ Suspect, Scared Pale as Police Swarmed His House in N.S.A. Case
text: GLEN BURNIE, Md. — Until the day the F.B.I. showed up, Harold T. Martin III seemed to be a familiar type in the sprawling Maryland suburbs where the employees and contractors of America’s largest intelligence agency make their home.

headline: Knicks’ Derrick Rose Expected in Court as Civil Trial in Rape Case Begins
text: LOS ANGELES — Derrick Rose is expected to belatedly join a federal civil trial Thursday, two days after his first exhibition game as a Knick, that will assess whether he and two friends raped his former girlfriend.

headline: Both Sides of a Fashion Eccentric
text: JON CARAMANICA When we found out that Rick Owens was opening a new store, it seemed like the opportunity for a Critical Shopper first: tag-team shopping.

headline: A.I.G. Ex-Chief Maintains He Knew of Nothing Improper in ‘Sham’ Deal
text: A lawyer for New York State finished questioning Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the insurance giant American International Group, without cracking his insistence that he did not know of anything improper in the transactions at the heart of his civil accounting fraud trial.

headline: What I Saw at Paris Fashion Week
text: On the final, frantic leg of a tour that begins in New York and caravans through London and Milan before arriving in Paris, here is what stood out.

headline: Twitter’s Fate: Marc Benioff of Salesforce Addresses Acquisition Talk
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Benioff, the founder and chief executive of Salesforce.com, showed up onstage on Wednesday afternoon at his biggest customer event of the year to talk up his business technology company’s products and strategy.

headline: Kava Gorna Photographs the Denim-Clad Bottoms of ‘It’ Girls
text: Age 37

headline: Hurricane Matthew: Photos of the Destruction in Haiti
text: Hurricane Matthew killed at least 25 people on its destructive path through Hispaniola, the Caribbean island that Haiti shares with the Dominican Republic, according to Reuters, but the authorities are just beginning efforts to assess the full scale of the damage.

headline: Neither Large Nor Small
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — We discuss today’s puzzle below, but first I want to point out the fact that, as a column and a community, we lack an anthem. Your mileage may vary, but I think it’s an important point; all nations have one, and while those who solve The New York Times Crossword are not exactly a nation, we are a community. And to me, that means we should have a song.

headline: Review: ‘The Roads to Home’ Offers Gossip and Insanity Most Genteel
text: For the women in Horton Foote’s “The Roads to Home,” which opened on Wednesday night at the Cherry Lane Theater, talking is close kin to breathing, and almost as essential to their survival. The three female characters in this plaintive, meandering trilogy of short plays are all displaced persons of a sort, uprooted from the Texas or Louisiana towns where they grew up and where they still live in their thoughts.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 3, Episode 3: Carry On, My Wayward Son
text: She’s the character formerly known as Boo-Boo Kitty and currently (reluctantly) referred to as Mrs. Lucious Lyon, but whatever you call her, Anika uttered two of the best lines of the night in this week’s “Empire.” Feuding with Lucious over what is effectively her house arrest in his mansion, Anika warns the Lyon king not to mess with her anymore. “When you push me,” she says, “I push back harder.”

headline: Why the Word ‘Fiancé’ Is Falling Out of Fashion
text: The day after my wedding, I turned to my partner of many years and, for the first time, called him “husband.” I was thrilled.

headline: Theranos to Close Labs and Lay Off 340 Workers
text: Theranos, the embattled blood-testing company, announced on Wednesday that it would close its laboratory operations, shutter its wellness centers and lay off about 340 employees, around 40 percent of its work force.

headline: A List of Missed Chances, but Few Answers, in Fatal Abuse Case
text: The array of city officials seated with Mayor Bill de Blasio in the Blue Room of City Hall on Wednesday reflected the pinball nature of a boy’s short life of abuse, observed by police officers, school staff members and investigators at the Administration for Children’s Services.

headline: Racial Bias Claim Looms Over Bronx School as Administrators Exit
text: So far, the turmoil at a public school in the Bronx has cost two principals and a district superintendent their jobs, has sparked a lawsuit and has a local assemblyman defending himself against claims that he is trying to keep minority children out of the school. And it’s not over yet.

headline: A New Bronze Age for Wristwatches
text: In an effort to stay au courant in the 21st century, watchmakers have been turning more and more to high-tech materials that seem borrowed from NASA: carbon fiber (the IWC Ingenieur Carbon Performance Ceramic), ultralight polymer (the Breitling Avenger Hurricane), ceramic (the Bell & Ross BR 03-92 Heritage Ceramic), even synthetic sapphire (the Hublot Big Bang Unico Sapphire).

headline: ‘Designated Survivor’ Season 1, Episode 3: The Two Shows
text: When you get promoted, everything moves faster. You deal with new responsibilities and unfamiliar systems. You’re forced to make harder decisions on a shorter timetable.

headline: Madison Bumgarner and One Big Blast Leave the Mets Blanked and Blue
text: Baseball can be so cruel. The Mets injected hope into New York with a spirited sprint to the playoffs, posting the best record in baseball during a six-week stretch and overcoming injuries that could have crippled their season. The Mets then escaped trouble so many times in Wednesday’s win-or-go-home National League wild-card game against the San Francisco Giants that they appeared capable of conquering the October legend Madison Bumgarner.

headline: Building a ‘Good’ Anthropocene From the Bottom Up
text: Over the last few years, I’ve gotten to know a determined cast of characters in academia aiming to identify paths to a good Anthropocene — Anthropocene being the closest thing there is to common shorthand for this span of human-dominated planetary history unfolding around us.

headline: Corrections: October 6, 2016

headline: The Giants Rely on a Familiar Formula, and a Great Equalizer

headline: The Supreme Court Revisits Insider Trading
text: Illegal insider trading goes on every day, and it is often difficult to detect and prosecute. But it is a fraud that harms public confidence in securities markets and unfairly disadvantages investors who are not privy to the confidential information. On Wednesday, the Supreme Court revisited this complex but important area of law for the first time in two decades.

headline: Is It O.K. to Find Sexual Satisfaction Outside Your Marriage?
text: I am married and have three children with my husband. For the most part, our lives are happy. My husband and I have a good relationship and are active in our children’s lives. However, I am utterly unsatisfied sexually. I need a bit more than occasional vanilla sex to feel content in that area (nothing too crazy, mind you). When my husband and I first started dating some years ago, I gently brought this matter up to him a handful of times during the course of regular conversation. His answers to me seemed to imply that he was the type who took some time to warm up to new ideas. With this in mind, I moved forward with him, believing that eventually our sex life would become more adventurous. It hasn’t. It has been seven years since we became a committed couple, and if anything, our sex has become more boring and certainly less frequent.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Life of Marshall Hodgson
text: Viewed in the least charitable terms, academia is a small fraternity of ambitious backbiters engaged in the production of work so dense that only other members of the order can hope to understand it. But some scholars arrive on the scene bearing such a combination of intellect, urgency and charisma that their achievements resonate long after the Festschrift is printed and the memorial lecture empties out.

headline: Judge John Hodgman Rules on Learning the Bagpipes
text: Liz writes: My fiancé is interested in learning the bagpipes. He claims that you can make good money playing weddings, funerals and St. Patrick’s Days. He plays no other instruments, does not read music and has failed at taking up other pursuits. Should he be allowed to do this?

headline: Review: In Nate Parker’s ‘The Birth of a Nation,’ Must-See and Won’t-See Collide
text: Can going to a movie be a moral obligation? A political gesture? There are occasions when various interested parties — filmmakers, publicists and perhaps especially critics — would like you to think so. Buying a ticket can become a test of seriousness, of personal commitment to a position or a cause. Jerry Seinfeld’s sitcom mom would not rest until her son had fulfilled the duty to watch “Schindler’s List.” (“Oh, you have to go. You have to!”) To make other plans would have been a filial, tribal and ethical betrayal, a lapse only a few steps removed from outright Holocaust denial.

Now, when Ms. Hutcherson’s time comes, Tinka and Sweetie will be allowed to rest in peace in her family’s plot: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo recently signed a law allowing cemeteries for people to inter pets alongside their owners.

We both visited in the first weeks and were overwhelmed by the magnitude of the space itself and the story that the museum — the Blacksonian, if you will (and, boy, will we!) — tells about the founding and development of this country.

headline: 1941: Nazis Drive Toward Moscow

The Russians were said to be resisting strongly, but little official news was available here regarding the trend of the fighting.

headline: West Bank Settlers Prepare for Clash, With Israeli Government
text: AMONA OUTPOST, West Bank — Thousands of Israeli police officers stormed this hilltop settler outpost in the occupied West Bank to raze nine illegally built homes. Settlers and their supporters hurled cinder blocks at the officers, who charged on horseback and beat protesters with batons. The homes were torn down, but 300 people were injured and the emotional scars ran deep. Some later called it a pogrom.

headline: More Asian-Americans Are Identifying as Democrats, Survey Finds

headline: The White House Rule: No Tax Returns, No Job
text: As ethics counsel to the current president and his predecessor, we scrutinized their tax returns before they were released every year. We also worked with our colleagues to review many tax returns of presidential nominees for cabinet and other positions. Based on the few pages of Donald J. Trump’s 1995 tax returns that have become public, we have come to the conclusion that no one in his position would have been nominated, much less confirmed by the Senate, during either of the administrations we served. The same is true of any modern administration of a president from either party.

He manipulates news coverage in many ways, including letting cronies snatch control of national media outlets that fell on bad times. Eisenhower.

headline: ‘Valentin de Boulogne,’ Bright Star in Caravaggio’s Orbit
text: A canon is not a static list of dead white men. It’s an assertion of who from the past can speak to the present, and its shape is always up for negotiation. “Valentin de Boulogne: Beyond Caravaggio,” a big Baroque blast of a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is the first exhibition anywhere devoted to a French painter whose theatrically lit tableaus of musicians, cardsharps and saints now stand in slight obscurity. It is also, quite explicitly, an application for canon membership, a full-throated bid to place Valentin (1591-1632) alongside Jusepe de Ribera and Georges de La Tour as a pioneer of the early 17th century.

headline: Mike Pence Disavows Donald Trump’s Earlier Proposal Barring Muslims
text: The Trump campaign appeared to disavow one of its most provocative policy proposals on Thursday, as Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana said explicitly that Donald J. Trump no longer wanted to impose a temporary ban on Muslim immigration to the United States.

headline: Review: ‘All That Man Is,’ and a Lot He Is Not, in David Szalay’s View
text: David Szalay writes with voluptuous authority. He possesses voice rather than merely style, and you climb into his new novel, “All That Man Is,” as if into an understated luxury car. The book has a large, hammerlike engine, yet it is content to purr. There’s a sense of enormous power held in reserve.

headline: Daily Report: The Feds Can’t Resist Silicon Valley’s Data

headline: Motorcycle Bomb Near Istanbul Police Station Wounds at Least 10
text: ANKARA, Turkey — A motorcycle bomb exploded near a police station in Istanbul on Thursday, wounding at least 10 people, Turkish officials said.

headline: How the Berenstain Bears Found Salvation
text: My 4-year-old son is obsessed with the Berenstain Bears. When bedtime rolls around, I no longer ask him what book he wants to read, but which Berenstain Bears book he would like. And who could blame him? Stan and Jan Berenstain’s 50-year-old series, with its family of bears living in a big tree house down a sunny dirt road deep in Bear Country, covers the waterfront of possible toddler experiences: everything from “Trouble at School” to “Too Much Birthday” to “Messy Room” to “Go to the Doctor.” And for that reason, the books are easily deployed by scheming parents like myself to inoculate against potentially unsettling changes that might frighten a 4-year-old. When my wife and I were set to take a child-free overseas trip, we read and reread “Week at Grandma’s” with my son as preparation; when summer rolled around, we pulled out “Go to Camp.”

headline: Micki Pellerano Reads Jenny Hval’s Tarot
text: The singer-songwriter visited the artist and occultist at his home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, for a very personal consultation.

headline: A Brooklyn Artist Reads a Norwegian Singer’s Tarot
text: On “Blood Bitch,” Jenny Hval’s beguiling new album, the avant-garde musician sings about menstruation and vampires, blood and politics. A spiritual successor to Kate Bush, Arthur Russell and Björk, Hval uses her breathy voice, programmed beats and Arp Odyssey synthesizer to invoke a pop cosmogony of feminism, humor, sensuality and noise. “It really is a subconscious album,” she says. “I think that I’m probably a little too good with the intellectual side of things after I’ve finished an album. I make it all up.” The music on “Blood Bitch” is an elemental experience; one can imagine moon cycles guiding rhythms, or the tides inspiring its looping melodies. Which is why it’s a surprise that, until very recently, Hval knew almost nothing about astrology.

headline: U.N. Syria Envoy Offers to Escort Rebel Fighters From Aleppo
text: GENEVA — The top United Nations diplomat for the Syria conflict proposed a new truce on Thursday, in hopes of averting what he called the destruction of rebel-held eastern Aleppo by Russian and Syrian forces. He offered to personally escort the jihadist fighters in the area to safety if the bombing is halted.

headline: Three’s a Trend: White Dresses, With Roomy Sleeves
text: Continuing what’s emerged as a theme in Milan and Paris — unexpected plays on volume — several designers have put a spin on the classic white dress by adding exaggerated rounded sleeves. Back in Milan, Salvatore Ferragamo showed a stark white design with sleeves that were ruched to add dimension. The young designer Jacquemus, whose obscure silhouettes put him on the map, sent out a short white shirtdress with eye-catching round sleeves on the first day of Paris Fashion Week. And a few days ago, Stella McCartney’s version of the roomy sleeve trend came with a poplin below-the-knee dress.

headline: Florida’s Vulnerability Tested as Hurricane Matthew Hugs Coast
text: A lot has changed in Florida since Oct. 22, 2005, when Hurricane Wilma roared west to east across the peninsula at Category 3 strength, making it the last major hurricane (storms in that category and stronger) to come ashore in the United States. On coasts there and elsewhere in hurricane danger zones, populations and development have grown and spread tremendously in a long storm lull.

headline: David Beckham Makes His Presence Felt at Kent & Curwen
text: LONDON — David Beckham strode into the Kent & Curwen showroom here, just one block from the men’s wear mecca of Jermyn Street. He smiled amiably at the small gathering of fashion reporters; posed for a picture with Suzy Menkes, the Vogue International editor, who would soon post on  Instagram, and briefly rubbed his close-cropped beard before announcing that he wanted to make one thing perfectly clear.

headline: Tips for Landing a Career at Your Father’s Software Company
text: Finding a career that’s right for you at your father’s software company is one of the more difficult tasks you will encounter as you enter your 30s. But it can be exciting, too! If you set realistic goals and put your mind to it, there’s no reason you won’t find gainful employment at the company your father runs.

headline: A Mother Criticizes Vince Staples, and the Rapper Defends Her
text: Musicians do not usually respond with patience when listeners refer to their music as “filth.”

headline: At Paris Fashion Week, a Season of Big Changes
text: The focus of the spring/summer 2017 Paris Fashion Week was undoubtedly, relentlessly, on the new. New labels, new designers at houses, lots of new clothes, a few new ideas. You may wind up asking: “What’s new?” The last five years have been characterized by that situation. Newness is nothing new.

headline: Backstage and Now the Boss: ‘The Only Girl in the Building’
text: Jennifer Diaz first stepped onto the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House at 11, as an extra in “I Pagliacci” and “La Bohème.” For the next three years, it became her second home, as she regularly visited her father, who is still the Met’s night crew manager after more than three decades.

headline: In Fight for Aleppo, Tangled Alliances in Syria Add to Chaos
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian civil war, and the intense new ground battle in the divided city of Aleppo, is often seen as a contest between a chaotic array of rebel groups and the Russian-backed government of President Bashar al-Assad. But the reality is that Mr. Assad’s side is increasingly just as fragmented as its opponents, a panoply of forces aligned partly along sectarian lines but with often-competing approaches and interests.

headline: Wells Fargo Scandal Blunts a Weapon in Banks’ Regulatory Fight
text: Wells Fargo has deprived banks of a Washington standard-bearer. Big lenders hoped to piggyback on their rival’s lack of Wall Street taint to resist proposals to curb pay and ban merchant banking. But the fake-accounts scandal weakens Wells Fargo’s ability to lead the charge.

headline: Donald Trump Takes Advantage of a Republican Party Pitted Against Itself
text: Four years ago, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, won the first fall debate with a smoothly delivered promise of cooperation. While President Obama had rebuffed Republicans, Mr. Romney would “work on a collaborative basis” with Democrats.

headline: Tim Coppens Likes Grooming Products With Soul
text: “I don’t believe in the miracle of product,” the Belgian fashion designer Tim Coppens said. When it comes to grooming, he takes a pragmatic approach.

headline: The Best of Michael Pollan for The New York Times
text: In the introduction to his essay on the Obama administration’s failure to take on corporate agriculture in this week’s Food Issue, Michael Pollan writes about an open letter to the president that he published in the magazine eight years ago. Pollan has been writing for The Times much longer, starting with his articles in the magazine about lawns and gardens in the 1980s. Since then he has primarily examined all the complicated ways we obtain the food we eat.

headline: Over 190 Countries Adopt Plan to Offset Air Travel Emissions
text: Governments from more than 190 countries on Thursday adopted a measure that for the first time will reduce the climate impact of international jet travel.

headline: An Affair to Forget
text: My husband’s co-worker is going to be the best man at a wedding. But he has shared with several colleagues his concern over taking part in the ceremony: The groom-to-be told him that he cheated on his fiancée with a woman with whom all three of them work. (The couple has had trouble with fidelity before; they broke up briefly but reunited.) The best man encouraged the groom to be honest with his fiancée, telling him it could be an issue later. But the groom resisted. We all feel strongly that the co-worker should not act as best man. What would you recommend?

headline: A Potter’s Appealing Artistry, Broadcast on Social Media
text: Eric Landon, the co-founder of Tortus, a pottery studio in Copenhagen, has won serious accolades, including the 2015 Danish Design Award for Craftsman of the Year, for his work: simple, organic shapes glazed in appealingly muted pastels. And, in an age of fetishistic obsession with objects that are handcrafted, the 40-year-old Milwaukee native has harnessed the power of social media to do better than simply make the claim: He’ll show you exactly how it’s done, in mesmerizing Instagram videos that have earned him nearly 600,000 followers. Think “Ghost” without Demi Moore or the Righteous Brothers soundtrack.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Louis Vuitton, Moncler Gamme Rouge and Miu Miu
text: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Paris on Wednesday.

text: For four decades “Live From Lincoln Center” has been a television standby. On Friday the arts complex will try something new: Think of it as “Facebook Live From Lincoln Center.”

text: Updated | Believe us — not every show in New York costs as much as a ticket to “Hamilton.” Here are five that will cost you just a few Hamiltons of your own, with our expert guidance on what to expect if you go:
