headline: Some I.V.F. Experts Discourage Multiple Births
text: This summer Louise Brown, the world’s first “test tube” baby, celebrated her 38th birthday as a mother of two naturally conceived children. In the decades since Ms. Brown’s celebrated birth, the techniques of in vitro fertilization, or I.V.F., have improved tremendously, resulting in an estimated five million babies worldwide born to couples unable to conceive on their own.

headline: When Do You Worry About a Picky Eater?
text: I saw one of the white-food kids a couple of weeks ago — a 9-year-old boy who lives on French fries, chicken fingers, white rice and white bread. Some white-food kids are so strict that their parents have to warn the restaurant that if there’s a little ceremonial dusting of parsley on the French fries, the child won’t eat them.

headline: A Frog Dies in Atlanta, and a World Vanishes With It
text: Atlanta — Two weeks ago, the last known Rabbs’ fringe-limbed tree frog died in a biosecure safehouse at the Atlanta Botanical Garden. Its distinctive, barklike call was last heard in the wild, as far as we know, in a Panamanian forest in 2007.

headline: Tourists Behaving Badly: Name-and-Shame Effort Fails to Fix China’s Image
text: BEIJING — Two young Chinese tourists carve their names on the Great Wall. Hundreds of picnickers leave their garbage moldering on the banks of the Yellow River.

headline: Trump’s Second Debate, in Brief
text: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: California Today: San Francisco Fields a Mental-Health SWAT Team
text: Good morning.

headline: Taiwan’s President Calls for New Talks With Beijing
text: HONG KONG — Taiwan’s president delivered a resounding affirmation of its freely elected government on Monday, noting that its deepening foothold on the island stands in stark contrast to the authoritarian government of mainland China.

headline: Britain’s Economy Was Resilient After ‘Brexit.’ Its Leaders Learned the Wrong Lesson.
text: This article must begin with a mea culpa. When British voters decided in June that they wanted to depart the European Union, I agreed with the conventional wisdom that the British economy would probably slow and that uncertainty put it at risk of recession.

headline: What I Learned About a Vanished New York From Gloria Steinem
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the Times Metro reporter John Leland reveals some of the many delightful nuggets of lesser-known New York City history recently shared with him by Gloria Steinem.

headline: Britain’s Nuclear Cover-Up
text: OXFORD, England — Last month, the British government signed off on what might be the most controversial and least promising plan for a nuclear power station in a generation.

headline: Was That a Debate? Or Were the Candidates Just Trying to Go Viral?
text: At the end of a rough night in the first presidential debate, Donald J. Trump congratulated himself for his restraint in not attacking his opponent with her husband’s sexual history.

headline: Women, Children and Razor Wire: Inside a Compound for Boko Haram Families
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Beyond the tall, concrete walls of a fortified compound, the authorities are holding a special group of detainees: the wives and children of Boko Haram commanders.

headline: 1966: Two U.S. Satellites Collide
text: MADRID — Two unmanned U.S. satellites collided in outer space last year [1965] but survived the five-mile-per-second crash, a U.S. space official told the 17th Astronautical Congress here today [Oct. 10]. The announcement was the most sensational statement on the opening day of the congress, in which 1,200 scientists from 30 countries are taking part.

headline: At a Christian College, Student Journalism Gets Religious
text: If you choose to enroll at my small evangelical liberal arts college in Illinois, you’ll learn quickly that the Wheaton community is very much into prayer.

headline: The Best Team in the N.F.L.? Right Now, It’s the Vikings
text: Five weeks have been played in the N.F.L. season. The Denver Broncos, the reigning Super Bowl champions, have lost. So have the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers. Playing without Tom Brady, the New England Patriots also lost.

headline: Paul Ryan Turns Focus From Donald Trump to House Races, Roiling G.O.P.
text: The House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, dealt a hammer blow to Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy on Monday, dashing any remaining semblance of Republican unity and inviting fierce backlash from his own caucus by announcing that he would no longer defend Mr. Trump.

headline: 1891: Steel Mills Clogged
text: Steel mills are reported to be more concerned about inability to make appreciable headway against the mass of orders already upon the books than in obtaining new contracts. Domestic consumers’ needs for the first half of next year are far from being satisfied, and the foreign demand for commercial forms would take up a large, additional tonnage if mills could promise shipments before July, 1917. Russia continues negotiating for 60,000 tons of barbed wire, and the closing of contracts for 7,500 more railroad carriages, requiring 75,000 tons of steel, is imminent. The great activity was in the Pittsburg and Chicago districts. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Oct. 11, 1891

headline: With Colombia’s Peace Deal in Doubt, a Battered Town Fears a Return to War
text: BOJAYÁ, Colombia — Of all the acts of violence that have scarred Colombia during five decades of armed conflict, few have cut so deep for so many as the slaughter that occurred in this municipality 14 years ago.

headline: What 50 Years of Earthquakes and Volcanic Eruptions Look Like
text: Earth has a violent heartbeat.

headline: Holiday Cooking
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Dozens Believed Killed as Violence Erupts in Myanmar
text: YANGON, Myanmar — At least 24 people were believed on Monday to have died in western Myanmar after unknown assailants attacked police outposts on Sunday near the border with Bangladesh.

headline: Spending More Just to ‘Save’ Money Is a Self-Defeating Strategy
text: Just over a week ago, we learned that in 1995 Donald Trump “claimed almost a billion dollars in operating losses that could be used to avoid future federal income taxation.” On Sunday night during the presidential debate, he bragged about his tax expertise.

headline: Is Ralph Lauren Going to Be Hillary Clinton’s Dresser in Chief?
text: Has Hillary Clinton found her dresser in chief? It would appear that way.

headline: Hurricane Matthew’s Toll Rises; Flooding Strands 1,500 in North Carolina
text: ■ Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina said Monday that an urgent rescue effort was underway in Lumberton, where a levee breach in the wake of Hurricane Matthew forced people to their rooftops.

headline: Daily Report: Your Choice of Computer Voice is Predictable
text: Let’s face it: You’re probably not thinking about technology right now. You’re watching highlights of Sunday night’s presidential debate. You’re tweeting about it. Reading about it. Captivated by the latest outrage that makes Nixon’s flop sweat in the Kennedy debate seem, well, not exactly a big deal.

headline: In Haiti, a City’s Race Into the 21st Century Is Ruined by a Hurricane
text: JÉRÉMIE, Haiti — Things had been looking up in Jérémie, a coastal city marooned on the tip of Haiti’s southern peninsula. It had recently gotten its first decent road link to the rest of the country, a new highway through the rugged mountains that brought development. Cellphone service had finally begun, enabling farmers and businesses to flourish. The city was racing into the 21st century, dreaming of advanced agriculture and tourism in one of Haiti’s few nature preserves.

headline: Trump Campaign Tried to Seat Bill Clinton’s Accusers in V.I.P. Box
text: An extraordinary backstage confrontation between Donald J. Trump’s campaign and the staff of the Presidential Commission on Debates unfolded just minutes before the debate on Sunday night after Mr. Trump tried to give seats in his V.I.P. box to a group of women who have accused former President Bill Clinton of making unwanted sexual advances.

headline: Solange Edges Out Bon Iver to Secure Her First No. 1 Album
text: In an unusual face-off on the Billboard chart, Solange and Bon Iver competed for this week’s top spot with highly acclaimed, left-of-center new albums, and Solange won by a nose.

headline: Horse Racing
text: This week’s challenge was inspired by Todd Unger, chief digital officer and chief marketing officer of the Daily Racing Form, horse racing’s dominant multiplatform media and e-commerce company. Let’s experience a bit of that equestrian energy with —

headline: Ken Bone's Debate Moment
text: Ken Bone, an audience member who asked a question about energy policy at the second presidential debate on Sunday, has become an internet sensation.

headline: Donald Trump, Barbarian at the Debate
text: What the hell did I just watch in that presidential debate last night?

headline: Freeing the Gmail New Message Window
text: Q. When using Gmail on the web, is there a way to occasionally make a new message a free-floating window that I can move around the screen, instead of having it anchored down at the bottom of the inbox?

headline: Coke and Pepsi Give Millions to Public Health, Then Lobby Against It
text: The beverage giants Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have given millions of dollars to nearly 100 prominent health groups in recent years, while simultaneously spending millions to defeat public health legislation that would reduce Americans’ soda intake, according to public health researchers.

headline: From ‘Locker Room Talk’ to ‘Muslims Report Stuff,’ the Internet Strikes Back
text: As the presidential election comes down to the wire, it seems as if Americans are grasping at anything to cope with the deluge of vitriol emerging from an increasingly bitter campaign.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Atlanta’ and ‘Supergirl’
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: At River Café, Breakfast as a Celebratory Event
text: At the River Café, on the East River, a goal is to provide a classic high-level breakfast “in the style of the grand hotels of Europe,” said the owner, Michael O’Keeffe. Though he is still tweaking the menu, his weekday eye-opener features choices like smoked salmon Benedict or avocado toast with poached eggs, and wines, Champagne and gentle pastel-hued cocktails. “Everyone stays for a long time, an hour and a half or two, relaxing away from the hustle of the city in a celebratory setting, ordering cocktails, Champagne and a surprising amount of caviar,” he said: Breakfast 8:30 to 11:30 a.m. Monday to Friday, the River Café, 1 Water Street (Old Fulton Street), Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn, 718-522-5200, rivercafe.com.

headline: West Side School Rezoning
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dizzying, Beautiful Stack of Pearls
text: The multifaceted Parisian designer Pierre Hardy says the bold jewelry he creates for the house of Hermès is inspired by shape and feeling rather than particular gemstones. This dizzyingly sinuous cuff, nearly three inches high, is a diamond-rimmed roller coaster of 150 pearls in varying sizes, as well as a meditation on the passage of time. Within the curvilinear rose-gold armature, the pearls seem to flow from day into night, shifting in shade from the luminous white of a snowy morning to the bottomless gray-black of midnight.

headline: A Private Solution to Deutsche Bank’s Public Woes
text: Deutsche Bank’s sliding share price and capital shortfall call for some creative solutions. And they do not get much more out of the ordinary than an idea that Germany’s corporate titans might take stakes in the lender to help it manage the impact of a potential $14 billion fine from American regulators, as Handelsblatt reported on Oct. 6. It is a less nutty concept than it sounds.

headline: Cheese Made in Switzerland but Aged in Queens
text: Murray’s Cheese often buys young cheeses from artisanal producers and ages them in its “caves” in Queens. The latest is an Appenzeller-style mountain cheese from Walter Rass in Switzerland, whose mild, immature wheels are usually sold only in his village. At Murray’s, Mr. Rass’s cheeses are stored for nine months, acquiring a nutty, robust grassiness. They’re tart, with hints of caramel, and beg for a glass of sauvignon blanc: Annelies, $34.99 a pound, Murray’s Cheese shops, murrayscheese.com.

headline: Premier League Stars Score the Goals. He Scores Everything Else.
text: RICHMOND, England — Charles Porter and his staff of eight work from his office in a converted riding school on the grounds of Aske Hall, an old manor house set in the gentle, rolling hills of North Yorkshire. His Australian Labradoodles, Bertie and Cybil, spend their days lounging on a leather sofa by a roaring fire.

headline: Ken Bone Is Closer to Deciding, After Debate
text: A desperate America seeking distraction from an ugly political climate may have found a new sweetheart. He is Kenneth Bone, an undecided voter in a bright red sweater.

headline: Why Doesn’t the United States (Finally) Get Rid of the Penny?
text: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

headline: Stomping Grapes in Brooklyn
text: Stomping on grapes for wine has gone the way of the horse and buggy, but on occasion it is brought back for a touch of the past and some freewheeling fun. That’s what Mark Schwartz will try in front of his Brooklyn wine shop this weekend. Tubs of grapes will be hauled out for willing participants to try their hand — er, foot — at crushing, either barefoot or wrapped in plastic: Grape stomp, noon to 5 p.m. on Saturday, Little Mo Wine & Spirits, 1125 Nostrand Avenue (Midwood Street), Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, 718-363-2101, littlemowine.com.

headline: Katharine Hayhoe, a Climate Explainer Who Stays Above the Storm
text: LUBBOCK, Tex. — A member of Katharine Hayhoe’s church asked her a question after services a couple of weeks ago: “Do you feel our weather is getting more extreme?”

headline: In Experiment, Apes Have Humans Figured Out
text: Apes know what you’re thinking. Or at least an experiment suggests they do.

headline: Warming Relations in Person, Putin and Erdogan Revive Pipeline Deal
text: MOSCOW — Amid increasingly tense relations with the United States over Syria, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took advantage of a routine meeting in Istanbul on Monday to advance the Kremlin’s reconciliation with Turkey, including an agreement to revive a suspended natural-gas pipeline project.

headline: Cancer in Retreat on One Front: Fewer Children Are Dying
text: Children are dying less often from cancer, with substantial declines in all races and age groups, according to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics.

headline: Why’d You Do That? Printing Donald Trump’s Vulgarities
text: Coverage of the leaked 2005 audio tape of  Donald Trump speaking in lewd language about women has produced an onslaught of reader mail, mostly because of the vile words contained in the coverage. The majority of those writing in are asking how the decision was made rather than complaining about the choice to include such words. I went to the Times political editor Carolyn Ryan to ask some of the readers’ most frequent questions.

headline: Hatch Chiles in Mild, Medium or Hot
text: New Mexico is known for its chiles from the Hatch Valley in the southern part of the state; chiles with varying heat levels are grown there and labeled Hatch. Zia Green Chile Company of Brooklyn sells jars of medium-hot or hot green chiles from Hatch, along with mild red; all are simply cooked, diced and preserved with lime, garlic and salt. The medium-hot green is vegetal and smoky, the hot is powerful, and the red has more fire than you would expect. They’re worth keeping in the refrigerator as a go-to condiment or spicy addition to recipes. The company also sells fresh roasted chiles from New Mexico; the 2016 harvest is ready for pre-order for shipping in coming weeks: Zia Green Chiles, 16-ounce jars, $10; roasted chiles, $35 for five pounds, www.ziagreenchileco.com.

headline: After Nearly 44 Years, and 3 Major Terrorism Trials, a Judge Leaves the Bench
text: From his seat on the bench, Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy listened patiently to the man he would soon put in prison for the rest of his life.

headline: First a Room, and Now a Book of Chocolate
text: Grab that offset spatula, some parchment paper, many slabs of chocolate (60 to 100 percent cacao) and extra-large eggs, and you’re ready to tackle this new collection of recipes from the Chocolate Room, a cafe in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with a branch in Cobble Hill. Consider making a three-layer blackout-style cake (with the thoughtful option of a single layer), a classic chocolate cream pie, a flourless cake baked in a water bath, insanely rich chocolate ice cream or simple dark chocolate and walnut cookies. For each, the equipment needed is thoroughly detailed, as is the shelf life for the results, which can be surprising, like three to four days in the refrigerator for the chocolate cream pie: “There’s Always Room for Chocolate: Recipes From Brooklyn’s the Chocolate Room,” by Naomi Josepher, Jon Payson and Georgia Freedman (Rizzoli $32.50).

headline: Highlights From the Clinton Campaign Emails: How to Deal With Sanders and Biden
text: The latest leaked emails reveal the careful deliberations aides engaged in on even small details and showed a bitter dispute between the Clintons’ daughter and a top aide.

headline: Jamaican Rock Iguanas Get a Shot at a New Home in the Wild
text: Meet the Jamaican rock iguana. Its scaly body stretches around two feet long, tail not included. Slate blue spikes stick up along its spine, and a saggy sac of loose skin wraps around its head like a hoodless cowl. When cornered, it strikes with its front claws — one reportedly ripped an eye from a dog.

headline: Letters: Vast Majority of N.F.L. Retirees Favor Concussion Settlement
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Learning From Dogs as They Sniff Out Their World
text: Our daily tug of leash war goes like this. I tell Chico we’re taking a left. He yanks right, wet black nostrils burrowing in loamy leaf piles. Me versus a 15-pound Havanese, incensed by scent.

headline: What Story Did Debate Night Body Language Tell?
text: From the opening handshake that did not happen to the stone-faced stares and surly scowls, it was evident from watching Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton share a debate stage on Sunday night that their political differences have become personal and that the mutual distaste that they feel is very real.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic Revisits an Early Triumph of Its Director
text: Alan Gilbert, approaching the end of his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, briefly revisited an early triumph last week in the orchestra’s subscription concerts at David Geffen Hall. In 2010, Mr. Gilbert collaborated with the director Doug Fitch on an innovative staging of Gyorgy Ligeti’s satirical opera “Le Grand Macabre” (1978), an absurdist take on nothing less than the end of the world.

headline: Climate Change Blamed for Half of Increased Forest Fire Danger
text: Forest fires are burning longer and stronger across the western United States, lighting up the landscape with alarming frequency. Residents are forced to flee, homes are incinerated, wildlife habitats are destroyed, lives are lost. Last year, the Forest Service spent more than half its annual budget fighting fires.

headline: For G.O.P. Candidates, Renouncing Donald Trump Carries Dire Risks
text: Paula Barche Rupnik, a Republican from Scottsdale, Ariz., was planning to vote for Senator John McCain in his re-election campaign this year. But she changed her mind this weekend, after he rescinded his support for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Deutsche Bank and Walmart Face Same Gambit With Justice Dept.
text: When companies are caught up in an investigation, the question is almost always about how much they will have to pay the government to resolve the case. The negotiations can seem like a poker game, with one side throwing out a number while the other claims it would rather fight than agree to such a sum.

headline: Home and Work: Nata Janberidze and Keti Toloraia
text: Inside the homes and studio of a pair of emerging Georgian designers, who playfully spin the future out of their uneasy Soviet past.

headline: Georgia’s Emerging, Avant-Garde Designers to Know
text: Strictly speaking, Nata Janberidze and Keti Toloraia began their creative collaboration in a vacuum. When they started designing objects and interiors a ­decade ago, fresh out of art school, their hometown Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, a small country on the Black Sea that spent much of the 20th century as part of the Soviet Union, had no creative community for two young designers to gain inspiration from, or any local market for the one-of-a-kind groundbreaking pieces they designed under the distinctly Western, purposefully plain name Rooms.

headline: Donald Trump, ‘Locker-Room Talk’ and Sexual Assault
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tiger Woods Postpones Return, Saying He’s ‘Not Ready to Compete’
text: Three days after Tiger Woods committed to his first PGA Tour event in 14 months, he abruptly withdrew, leaving this week’s Safeway Open with twice as many tickets sold as a year ago but a fraction of the star power.

headline: #MyRunLooksLike: Show Us Your Marathon Training
text: We want a glimpse of your road to the marathon start line. Share your photos on Instagram using #MyRunLooksLike.

headline: Review: In ‘American Housewife,’ a Plus-Size Mom in the Land of Fitbits
text: “American Housewife,” an awful attempt to transplant “Roseanne” into the age of economic inequality, mistakes sophomoric for subversive. The show, which begins Tuesday on ABC, seems to be angling for what it views as an underserved demographic, all those malcontented Americans we keep reading about in connection with the presidential election, the ones who are stuck in a can’t-get-ahead life because the privileged class has mucked things up and taken all the money. In this show’s interpretation, the down-and-outs spend their days telling potty jokes, thinking the whole world hates them because of their weight, and in general emitting contempt for everyone and everything, including their own children.

headline: Tyson Foods, a Meat Leader, Invests in Protein Alternatives
text: Tyson Foods appears to be the first big meat company to invest in a business that, among other things, aims to reduce consumption of chicken, beef and pork by replacing it with plant proteins.

headline: Review: ‘Godzilla’ Returns, Again, With a Wink
text: You either like your “Godzilla” movies slick and high-budget, like the 1998 American version that starred Matthew Broderick, or you like them with a rickety, 1950s feel that evokes the original.

headline: Yale Rep Celebrates Its 50th Amid Nostalgia (and a Few Worries)
text: NEW HAVEN — Leave it to Robert Brustein, the outspoken founding director of Yale Repertory Theater, to raise tough questions at a celebration of the theater’s 50th anniversary this weekend.

headline: The Trees of New York City
text: Q. Why do I see only deciduous trees, not evergreens, planted along New York City streets?

headline: 5 One-Liners That Sum Up a Fiery Trump-Clinton Debate
text: The second presidential debate was one of the nastiest ever. There was no shortage of eye-rolls, sighs and gestures of faux politeness that dripped with sarcasm. After weeks of throwing flames from afar, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton let the zingers fly on Sunday night.

headline: Members of Congress Ask N.H.L. for More Concussion Information
text: Four members of Congress want more answers from Gary Bettman, the commissioner of the N.H.L., about what the league is doing, or not doing, about concussions in hockey.

headline: Species, Interrupted – Why it Matters When Extinction Silences a Tree Frog
text: When someone notable attains a certain age, newspapers assign reporters to draft advance obituaries, with just the top two or three paragraphs to add when the inevitable happens. As news spread late last month of the death of “Toughie,” the last known Rabbs’ fringe-limbed tree frog, I used Twitter to muse on whether media will have to start doing the same thing for species of living things that are on the brink of extinction:

headline: Musicians to Know: An R&B Duo With Indie-Film Cred
text: “The reason we don’t have a band name is just because we never expected it to pop like it did!” explains the musician and actor Brian “Sene” Marc. So when he makes R&B with the vocalist Denitia Odigie, they simply go by their names: Denitia and Sene.

headline: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton: More a Brawl Than a Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Soothing Ruffled Guests: Hotels Meet Threat of Bad Reviews
text: Pam and Larry Willis had recently purchased the Gables Wine Country Inn in California’s Sonoma wine region four years ago when they received it: their first TripAdvisor threat.

headline: Snooping in the Bathroom to Assess Credit Risk in China
text: KUNSHAN, China — Banks and other lenders typically look at borrowers’ credit histories, tax forms and other financial information to determine whether they will get paid back. In China, lenders also look at their bathrooms.

headline: Review: At Desert Trip, Rocking Beyond the Hits With a Vengeance
text: INDIO, Calif. — The past loomed, long and weighty, over Desert Trip, a three-night festival here with a lineup of baby boomers’ rock heroes. It was simply two sets a night: the Rolling Stones and Bob Dylan on Friday, Paul McCartney and Neil Young on Saturday and Roger Waters and the Who on Sunday. That lineup is to be repeated Friday through Sunday and perhaps never again.

headline: The Donald Trump We Always Knew
text: Watching Republican leaders and talking heads spin themselves dizzy over the second presidential debate would be entertaining if the situation was not so tragic.

headline: Review: Elena Ferrante Wants Privacy. Her New Book Implies Otherwise.
text: This month, an article by the Italian journalist Claudio Gatti was published, offering a theory about the identity of the real writer behind the pseudonym Elena Ferrante, based on “a monthslong investigation.”

headline: Nadia Murad, Yazidi Woman Who Survived ISIS Captivity, Wins Human Rights Prize
text: Fighters for the Islamic State abducted a young Yazidi woman named Nadia Murad, her siblings and their mother from their village in northern Iraq more than two years ago. Barely in her 20s, Ms. Murad was separated from her family, beaten and sexually assaulted.

headline: Letter From Congress to Gary Bettman
text: Members from the Congressional Committee on Energy and Commerce sent a letter to N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman regarding the league's concussion protocol.

headline: Taylor Mac’s Pop Marathon
text: The show “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music” began on Saturday at noon and ended at the same time on Sunday.

headline: Review: Taylor Mac’s 24-Hour Concert Was One of the Great Experiences of My Life
text: So after almost 21½ hours and two centuries’ worth of singing, dancing, and jiggling; after all 650 of us had been asked to re-enact everything from the Civil War and the Oklahoma land rush to white flight to the suburbs; after a narcotically swampy rendition of “Amazing Grace” and a production of “The Mikado” that glowed in the dark because its minstrelsy might make sense if it was set on Mars; after visionary drag-queen costumes that called to mind descriptions like geisha Andrews Sister and Tiki apocalypse; after we’d stood in lines for small portions of bread and split pea soup at 3 a.m. and not many people took the bread (because even during a poignant Depression homage some people will still refuse to eat a carb); after we’d batted around an enormous stars-and-stripes penis balloon whose design really did look more like the flag of Puerto Rico and then made a funeral procession for Judy Garland’s corpse; after a mash-up of the Bee Gees’ “Stayin’ Alive” and Led Zeppelin’s “Kashmir”; after Taylor Mac, the performance artist who dreamed this whole thing up, had cavorted onstage and in the laps and arms of strangers; after all of this — the delirium, the mania, the possibly simulated sex — it might have been the balloon that broke us.

headline: Billy Joel-Loving Academics Get in a Piano Man State of Mind
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — Morgan Jones, a high school music teacher from Swaziland, was holding court at a Steinway baby grand in the atrium of the Cornerstone Performing Arts Center at Colorado College. What the group of listeners had in common with the man at the piano was a love and near-encyclopedic knowledge of the Piano Man: Billy Joel.

headline: A YouTube Star Is All In, Professionally and Personally
text: The Netflix series “Haters Back Off” (which begins streaming on Friday) opens with the YouTube character Miranda Sings — an aggressively awful aspiring entertainer played by the writer and comedian Colleen Ballinger — looking into a camera and saying, “Hey, guys.” She’s seated, centered in the screen, with an overstuffed closet open behind her. It’s a note-perfect evocation of the handmade, homemade YouTube aesthetic by an artist who has forged a successful career from affectionately parodying the medium that has brought her fame.

headline: Special Tax on Women: Trump Tape Is a Reminder of the Cost of Harassment
text: The leaked footage of Donald J. Trump boasting of sexually harassing and assaulting women is just one particularly notable example of an all-too-common phenomenon: Far too many men treat women’s bodies as if they are fair game for anyone who happens to encounter them.

headline: How to Cook a Roast Sous Vide
text: This method produces juicy, tender meat that you can quickly sear, sauté or stir-fry for a weeknight meal.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
text: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Making Sous Vide Simplify Work for You
text: Increasingly affordable and easy to do, sous-vide immersion cooking has become trendy among food nerds who want precise control over the doneness of their meats.

headline: Donald Trump, Samsung, Yemen: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Beetle Battle
text: The bigger the mandibles, the more likely a male is to defeat a challenger for the attention of a female on a rotting log.

headline: Jaws: The Tale of the Fearsome Stag Beetle
text: You’ve heard of the Jaws of Life. How about the mandibles of power?

headline: Reginald K. Brack Jr., 79, Dies; Led Time Inc. Into Entertainment Era
text: Reginald K. Brack Jr., who as a top executive at Time Inc. helped shepherd the company’s sometimes uneasy transformation from a primarily journalistic enterprise into a multimedia and entertainment company, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 79.

headline: The Presidential Debate in Song: Who’s Gonna Work It Out?
text: Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the Gregory Brothers team up to present a musical mashup of highlights from the second 2016 presidential debate.

headline: The Presidential Debate in Song: Who’s Gonna Work It Out?
text: Absurd. Surreal. Farcical. Freakish. Unfathomable. These are just a few of the words that we’ve heard used to describe the 2016 election, plus several synonyms that we just looked up in a thesaurus to make the list look even longer and more weighty.

headline: Buffett Calls Trump’s Bluff and Releases His Tax Data
text: Warren E. Buffett is not running for president. But on Monday, Mr. Buffett, the billionaire investor, volunteered more detailed information about his income taxes than Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee, ever has.

headline: Photos and Detailed Maps Reveal Hurricane Matthew’s Brutal Aftermath in Haiti
text: The storm killed hundreds of people and left a path of destruction in western Haiti. Entire towns were turned into a mix of mud and debris.

headline: Ratings for Second Debate Dive 20 Percent
text: Maybe Americans are starting to get fed up with the ugly tone of this strange presidential election. Maybe viewers are tired of R-rated video clips and scorched-earth attacks.

headline: A Partisan Crowd Watches the Debate at the New Trump Hotel
text: WASHINGTON — Outside, a ribbon of lights swept up Pennsylvania Avenue toward the Capitol, and there was not a protester in sight. Inside the month-old Trump International Hotel, a Romanesque Revival structure just as grand, the second presidential debate had begun.

headline: Ranchers Tote Guns as Tribes Dig In for Long Pipeline Fight
text: CANNON BALL, N.D. — Ranchers are arming themselves before they climb onto tractors or see to their livestock. Surveillance helicopters buzz low through the prairie skies. Native Americans fighting to prevent an oil pipeline near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation are handing out thick blankets and coats and are building maple-pole shelters that can withstand North Dakota’s bitter winter.

headline: ISIS Media Output Drops as Military Pressure Rises, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The vaunted propaganda operations of the Islamic State, which helped lure more than 30,000 foreign fighters to Syria and Iraq, have dropped off drastically as the extremist group has come under military pressure, according to a study by terrorism researchers at West Point.

headline: Seinfeld’s ‘Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee’ Is on Market
text: In a potential blow to Crackle, the fledgling Sony Pictures Entertainment streaming service, Jerry Seinfeld’s hit online series “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee” is on the market.

headline: A Gift for the City of New York
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Emails Show How Clinton Aides Stage-Managed Her Keystone Shift
text: The Clinton campaign emails that were made public by WikiLeaks on Monday show the degree to which Hillary Clinton’s aides stage-managed her policy announcements, and the extent of their anxiety as they tried to explain her changed positions on certain issues. The following exchange reflects one example: her shift on the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: Threat to Jail Clinton Smacks of ‘Tin-Pot Dictators,’ Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — As president of the United States, Donald J. Trump would wield the power to carry out his vow to have a special prosecutor reopen the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails — if not to guarantee his threat to her that “you’d be in jail” if he ran the country.

headline: Ex-President of Brazil Faces New Corruption Charges
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Federal prosecutors filed new corruption charges on Monday against Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, raising pressure on him and his family over dealings in Angola, the oil-rich country where Brazilian companies have aggressively raised their profile over the last decade.

headline: Car Attacks in Denmark Spread ‘Like an Infection’
text: The arsonists appear to operate with little deference to class, equally at ease scorching a shiny new BMW or Mercedes as they are setting a battered old van ablaze.

headline: Hillary Clinton Aides Kept de Blasio at Arm’s Length, WikiLeaks Emails Show
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio came into office in 2014 telling a tale of two cities, where the poor and the working class were finding it increasingly hard to get by, while the moneyed elite got more moneyed by the day. He envisioned himself as a leader of a growing liberal movement both in New York City and across the nation.

headline: Wells Fargo Reshuffles Top Ranks, Rallying Around Its No. 2
text: Wells Fargo, under fire from all sides because of a long-running scandal in which employees set up illegal accounts to meet sales quotas, announced a restructuring of its top management on Monday, solidifying the leadership structure beneath Timothy J. Sloan, who is widely expected to succeed John G. Stumpf, the bank’s embattled chairman and chief executive.

headline: Jacob Neusner, Judaic Scholar Who Forged Interfaith Bonds, Dies at 84
text: Jacob Neusner, a religious historian of enormous breadth and productivity and one of the world’s foremost scholars of Jewish rabbinical texts, died on Saturday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: What Exactly Is ‘Locker-Room Talk’? Let an Expert Explain
text: My father was a coach and the manager of a sporting goods store that installed and maintained equipment at athletic facilities. By the time I was in third grade, I had already spent countless days and nights in locker rooms — at colleges, high schools, prep schools, private adult clubs, you name it.

headline: Were He Seeking Any Other Job, Trump Would Be Flagged by H.R.
text: Donald Trump describes himself as a businessman. And he says he wants to run the government more like a business.

headline: Twitter Is Said to Be in Continued Talks With Salesforce
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last week, Twitter’s fate has appeared to be murkier than ever. The troubled social media company, which has been engaged in talks to sell itself, seemed to be running out of potential buyers.

headline: Mark Burnett Says He Can’t Release ‘Apprentice’ Video of Donald Trump
text: Mark Burnett, the reality show impresario, has faced mounting demands in recent days to release old video from his series “The Apprentice,” on speculation that Donald J. Trump was captured on camera making vulgar remarks during his 11 years as the show’s host.

headline: Fleeing the Coast Before the Storm, Only to Be Trapped Inland
text: CERRO GORDO, N.C. — Diamond Hansen and Darryl Clark rented a room in a Super 8 for a month, hoping it was a springboard to a fresh start in Myrtle Beach, S.C. Then the evacuation order came for Hurricane Matthew, so they climbed into Mr. Clark’s Volvo and drove to a place that seemed safe, his uncle’s house well inland in rural North Carolina. But it was far from the haven they expected.

headline: Abby Wambach, Retired U.S. Soccer Star, Reflects on Her Addiction
text: Abby Wambach retired from the United States women’s national soccer team in December, ending a career that included two Olympic gold medals, a Women’s World Cup title and 184 goals, the most by any American player — male or female — in history.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist and Rangers Are Renewing Title Quest After Long Off-Season
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, the oldest Ranger, joined his teammates in a team-building exercise this weekend, which included visiting the National September 11 Memorial & Museum and participating in a Police Department tactical-training session.

headline: For Many Women, Trump’s ‘Locker Room Talk’ Brings Memories of Abuse
text: It was the author Kelly Oxford, a social media powerhouse, who got things started on Friday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day

headline: Despite Ken Thompson’s Short Stint as Brooklyn Prosecutor, Agenda May Endure
text: In New York politics, the city’s district attorneys have long been the edifices of elective office: legal lions presiding for years — often decades — over courthouse fiefs beyond the influence even of City Hall.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Campaign Strained to Hone Her Message, Hacked Emails Show
text: On the eve of the New Hampshire primary in February, a longtime aide to Bill Clinton was worried. Hillary Clinton was about to go down to defeat in the state, and the former president was despondent.

headline: New York City May Double Number of Food Vendor Permits
text: For eight years, Julia Chimborazo has sold Italian ice on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens, doing what she can to support her two young children and send money to a third, who still lives in her native Ecuador.

headline: Elizabeth F. Rohatyn, Supporter of Education and the Arts, Dies at 86
text: Elizabeth F. Rohatyn, a major supporter of numerous arts and educational organizations, including the New York Public Library, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.

headline: Herbert Irving, Sysco Co-Founder and $300 Million Hospital Donor, Dies at 98
text: Herbert Irving, a co-founder of the food services giant Sysco Corporation and a philanthropist who donated more than $300 million to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center, died on Oct. 3 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Nationals Take Series Lead Over Dodgers After Battle of Bullpens
text: LOS ANGELES — The way modern baseball has evolved, relievers have become invaluable, and in painstakingly slow fashion Monday at Dodger Stadium, the Washington Nationals and the Los Angeles Dodgers highlighted the need for dominant bullpens that are smartly deployed.

headline: In Debate on Syria, It’s Trump vs. Pence, and Clinton vs. Obama
text: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, Syria’s civil war has vexed and divided the Obama administration. Now, barely a month before the election, those tensions are finally spilling into the presidential race.

headline: Review: ‘Oh, Hello on Broadway’ Stars an Even Odder Couple
text: The dirty old men have occupied Broadway. They are an army of only two, yet they seem destined to conquer and slay anyone who ventures into the Lyceum Theater, where they have set up their festering — and, admit it, stupendously entertaining — camp.

headline: Pep Squad Member’s Lament
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If you wind up with a bad case of earworm after you finish solving today’s puzzle by Sam “Not the Newsman” Donaldson and Doug Peterson, you have only them to blame. I solved their puzzle fairly swiftly, but came away with the song “CHEESE SO FINE” stuck in my head. And now I can’t get it out and all I want is cheese on a fancy cracker.

headline: ‘Go Back to China’: Readers Respond to Racist Insults Shouted at a New York Times Editor
text: It certainly felt like something of a moment for Asian-Americans in this country: an article about racist insults flung at one of their own, featured prominently in The New York Times, shared, posted and commented on thousands upon thousands of times.

headline: Theranos Sued by Investor Who Accuses It of Securities Fraud
text: Theranos, the beleaguered Silicon Valley blood-testing company, is being accused of securities fraud by a major investor who has sued contending “myriad deceptions, falsehoods and fraudulent conduct.”

headline: Australia’s Labor Party Blocks Referendum on Same-Sex Marriage
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s opposition Labor Party voted to block legislation to allow a public referendum on same-sex marriage, Bill Shorten, the party’s leader, said on Tuesday, effectively killing the nonbinding plebiscite that Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull had proposed for early next year.

headline: Cleveland Indians Are Rewriting a Hard-Luck Tale
text: BOSTON — The Cleveland Indians are not used to this. Their past is tortured, their present tattered. They have waited 68 years for a World Series title. Their chances seemed grim before this division series with the brawny Boston Red Sox.

headline: Indians Sweep Aside Ortiz’s Last Bit of Magic
text: BOSTON — Each time David Ortiz walked to the batter’s box, the fans at Fenway Park stood and cheered, a gesture that was partly a salute to his remarkable career and partly an entreaty to save the day once again.

headline: For New York City’s Homeless Children, Getting to School Is the Hard Part
text: Family workers carrying caseloads of 256 children at a time. A girl who had transferred to four different schools, one of them twice, by age 11. Attendance reports from multiple agencies, but with none held responsible for making sure that students actually went to school.

headline: Greylock Partners Says It Raised a $1 Billion Fund
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Greylock Partners, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, said it has raised a $1 billion fund as investors increase venture firm funding to highs not seen since the dot-com boom last decade.

headline: Telescope to Seek Earthlike Planet in Alpha Centauri System
text: A scientific research consortium on Tuesday announced plans to build and launch a privately financed telescope the size of a small washing machine in hopes of finding an Earthlike planet in the Alpha Centauri system, one of our closest cosmic neighbors.

headline: Hurricane Matthew’s Toll Rises; Flooding Hits North Carolina
text: ■ The storm’s death toll in the United States has climbed to more than two dozen. Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina said Tuesday that the state had recorded 14 fatalities. At least six people died in Florida, and the authorities in Georgia and South Carolina reported three deaths in each state.

headline: Atlantic Names Jeffrey Goldberg Its Editor in Chief
text: The Atlantic said on Tuesday that it had named Jeffrey Goldberg, a correspondent for the company since 2007, its next editor in chief, drawing an extensive search to a close.

headline: As Time Expires, a Buccaneers Kicker Finds Redemption
text: Roberto Aguayo kicked a 38-yard field goal as time expired, and the visiting Tampa Bay Buccaneers defeated the Carolina Panthers, 17-14, on Monday night.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Channel Zero: Candle Cover’ and ‘Prescription for Change’
text: Just in time for Halloween, Syfy adds an anthology horror series to its lineup, this one about child murders. “Frontline” examines the status of the fight against ISIS. And Macklemore speaks with President Obama about the country’s opioid crisis.

text: NATIONAL

headline: Fiat Chrysler Deal With Union Averts Strike in Canada
text: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles avoided a strike late Monday night by about 10,000 employees at three plants in Canada.

headline: Building Collapse in Chinese City of Wenzhou Kills at Least 22
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese state news media reported Tuesday that at least 22 people had died in the collapse of four residential buildings in an eastern city the day before, a toll that would make it one of the deadliest cases of its kind in recent years.

headline: Zymergen Raises $130 Million in New Round of Financing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Over its three-year life, Zymergen has focused on helping genetically engineer tiny microbes, while using advanced computing to help better automate the process.

text: 1. sexually exciting or gratifying

headline: On the Streets of Harlem, a Sense of ‘Erase and Replace’
text: Dawoud Bey’s large-scale photos of Harlem show the legendary cradle of African-American life confronting speculation, displacement and gentrification.

headline: In Queens, Seceding From the Homeless Crisis
text: “STOP the War on the Middle Class,” said one marcher’s sign. “Dump Communist de Blasio,” said another, the small “d” made from a hammer and sickle.

headline: Count Trump Among the Takers
text: Because Donald J. Trump hasn’t released his tax returns, we don’t know exactly what portion of his fortune he has sent the federal government. But in the second presidential debate, he confirmed that there were a number of years where he paid nothing at all.

headline: In Praise of Kenneth Bone
text: All hail Kenneth Bone! Mr. Bone was the fellow in a red sweater who rose to his feet near the end of Sunday night’s town hall debate. People are having a fine old time riffing on his genial manner, his festive sweater and the disposable camera he used to snap pictures after the event. But here’s the thing about Mr. Bone: He asked a smart question about energy policy, an issue largely overlooked in the debates so far, which in turn elicited from Hillary Clinton a mention of climate change, an issue that has been completely overlooked.

headline: Male Voters Finally Get Trump
text: The release of a 2005 recording showing Donald Trump gloating about sexual assault has cost him female voters. But by one measure, the tape has had a bigger impact on men. In an NBC News/SurveyMonkey poll conducted before the release of the tape, 45 percent of likely male voters said Mr. Trump does not respect women. Post-tape, that share rose to 55 percent.

headline: For Better Citizenship, Scratch and Win
text: China, with its largely cash economy, has a huge problem with tax evasion. Not just grand tax evasion, but the everyday “no receipt, please” kind, even though there have been harsh penalties: Before 2011, some forms of tax evasion were even punishable by death.

headline: When They Go Low, Do We Have to Go, Too?
text: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. Well, the race has defied my expectations and hit a new moral low. Where to start — the insult-driven second debate, the sensational pre-debate press conference Trump held on Facebook with a jury of Bill Clinton’s accusers, the revelation that Mrs. Clinton told Wall Street bankers that one has to have “private” and “public” positions, or Trump’s videotaped Caligula impression from 2005 that has dominated the news since Friday? You choose.

headline: The Supreme Court Is Being Hypocritical
text: The Supreme Court’s motto may be “equal justice under law.” But sometimes it seems more like “do as we say, not as we do.”

headline: America’s Moral Duty in Yemen
text: Airstrikes by a Saudi-led coalition that devastated a funeral in Yemen on Saturday make it clear that the United States must end its complicity in a civil war that has caused a humanitarian catastrophe in one of the world’s poorest countries and fueled extremism. It is within President Obama’s power to do so. Saudi Arabia and its Gulf state allies depend on Washington for aircraft, munitions, training and in-flight refueling. The United States also helps Saudi Arabia guard its borders.

headline: Donald Trump’s Sad, Lonely Life
text: The point of town hall debates is that regular voters get to ask questions. In every town hall I’ve seen, the candidate turns to the voter, listens attentively and directs the answer at least partially back to that person.

headline: A Great Fight of Our Times
text: Think, for a moment, about the stories that your family likes to tell about itself. They are probably miniature versions of the American story, with progress as the central theme.

headline: What the Nobel Peace Prize Prizes
text: Should the award only be given for actual achievements, or is it important to recognize those who aspire to peace?

headline: Henan Province, a Butt of Jokes in China, Gets a Champion in Court
text: BEIJING — Henan has a P.R. problem, but Jing Changshui has an answer. He’s suing.

headline: On the Streets of Harlem, a Sense of ‘Erase and Replace’
text: Dawoud Bey’s large-scale color photographs of Harlem vividly document a bustling and rapidly transforming neighborhood: a verdant Marcus Garvey Park; construction sites popping up for more luxury housing; street vendors hawking hats and used clothing; posters of black women’s hairstyles in the window of a hair weave distributor adjacent to a vacant lot; faded paper covering the windows of the legendary — and shuttered — Lenox Lounge; and white tourists intent on hearing gospel music waiting outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church.

headline: Sports Fans
text: What sports teams are you a fan of? How would you react if your team went on a 107-year losing streak? Do you think you would stay loyal?

headline: Jodi Picoult’s New Novel Reviewed by Roxane Gay
text: SMALL GREAT THINGSBy Jodi Picoult470 pp. Ballantine Books. $28.99.

headline: How Colin Kaepernick’s Protest Is Connecting Playing Fields to the Streets
text: A few days after the first presidential debate, LeBron James took a stand: He endorsed Hillary Clinton for president. The reasons he cited ranged from a belief that Clinton would “build on the legacy” of his “good friend” Barack Obama to her good works on behalf of children. James concluded with a passage about the “violence, of every kind, the African-American community is experiencing in our streets and seeing on our TVs.” He went on to say we need to be “unified” and “stand together — no matter where we are from or the color of our skin.” The measured tone was an echo of his appearance at the ESPY Awards in July, where he and his fellow N.B.A. stars Dwyane Wade, Carmelo Anthony and Chris Paul spoke out in a joint speech for “uniting communities” and ending violence.

headline: What’s Really Behind Trump’s Obsession With Clinton’s ‘Stamina’?
text: To Donald Trump, everything is negotiable, even getting old. At 70 — about 16 months older than Hillary Clinton — he would be the oldest person ever to step into the presidency, a fact he’s determined to talk his way around. “Here’s a woman — she’s supposed to fight all of these different things, and she can’t make it 15 feet to her car,” he told supporters at a recent rally in Pennsylvania. “She’s home resting right now.” He slackened his jaw and feigned stumbling across the stage, a dramatic re-enactment of the video that showed Clinton nearly collapsing from pneumonia in September. “Folks,” Trump announced, “we need stamina.”

headline: How Hillary Became ‘Hillary’
text: Two weeks after Hillary Clinton accepted the Democratic nomination for president, I flew to Little Rock, Ark., to visit a woman named Gay White. White is the widow of Frank White, a conservative Little Rock banker who in the spring, summer and fall of 1980 toured all 75 counties in Arkansas in a quixotic attempt to unseat the incumbent governor, Bill Clinton. Frank had no previous experience campaigning, but he proved to be an enthusiastic retail politician. Gay, then 32, accompanied him on his statewide tour of cattle auctions, courthouse squares, Walmart parking lots and chicken-processing plants. “Hi, I’m Gay White,” she would tell the people they met. “My husband’s running for governor, and I’d sure appreciate your vote.”

headline: Was it a Depressing Week in Politics for Women, or a Great One?
text: Dear Sue,

headline: A Man Booker Finalist: A China Where Music Was Life and Death
text: DO NOT SAY WE HAVE NOTHINGBy Madeleine Thien473 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

headline: Marina Abramovic: By the Book
text: The performance artist and author of “Walk Through Walls” doesn’t have a severe temperament: “I have a dark sense of humor which is very much from the Balkans — I love dirty jokes.”

headline: Tough Talk but Little Action From Lieberman as Israel’s Defense Minister
text: JERUSALEM — Israel has been challenged by land, sea and air in recent weeks, as security officials have braced for a wave of violence around the Jewish High Holy Days and the anniversary of the outbreak of Palestinian stabbing, shooting and automobile attacks that began a year ago.

headline: Trump’s Threat to Jail Clinton Also Targets Democracy’s Institutions
text: When Donald J. Trump told Hillary Clinton at Sunday’s presidential debate that if he were president, “you’d be in jail,” he was threatening more than just his opponent. He was suggesting that he would strip power from the institutions that normally enforce the law, investing it instead in himself.

headline: ‘I’m the Last Thing Standing Between You and the Apocalypse’
text: There can be days in this presidential campaign, if not weeks or months or maybe the entire thing, where you find yourself completely lost in dueling or blurry realities. It’s easy to get caught up in whatever is dominating a given moment. Everything gets so big and loud, and the candidates — famous to begin with — cease to even exist as human beings in front of you.

headline: Early Voting Could Point to Hillary Clinton Victory Well Before Nov. 8
text: With early voting already underway in many of the states that will decide the presidency, Hillary Clinton is beginning to reap the benefits of years of Democratic efforts to target and register voters, even as Republicans steadily close their disadvantage in party registration.

headline: ‘We Sleep Afraid, We Wake Up Afraid’: A Child’s Life in Yemen
text: Mohammed al-Asaadi is a father of four in Sana, the capital of Yemen, which has been caught in a war between Iranian-backed rebels and Saudi Arabia for more than two years. He is a former journalist now working in communications for Unicef.

headline: This City Is 78% Latino, and the Face of a New California
text: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Vicente Sarmiento remembers when the local Republican Party here posted uniformed guards at polling stations in a closely fought State Assembly race three decades ago and they hoisted signs in English and Spanish warning that noncitizens were prohibited from voting. The guards were removed after state elections officials threatened legal action.

headline: Were Donald Trump’s Comments on a 2005 Video Normal ‘Locker Room Talk‘?
text: By now, you probably have heard or read about videotaped remarks Donald Trump made in 2005 about women.

headline: Where Republicans in Competitive House and Senate Races Stand on Donald Trump
text: How the emergence of a 2005 recording of Donald J. Trump bragging about sexual assault is playing out in the tightest House and Senate races.

headline: In Face of ‘Brexit,’ Signs of E.U. Pulling Together
text: COPENHAGEN — As the European Union ponders a future without Britain, its No. 2 economy and strongest military power, Hamlet’s state of Denmark seems an appropriate place to pose anew his existential question: In the 21st century, is the bloc to be, or not to be?

headline: Giants Prevail in a Marathon Thriller and Prevent a Sweep by the Cubs
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the baseball rattled off the wall in the vast right-center-field expanse of AT&T Park — and out of the elastic grasp of Albert Almora Jr. — it set off a race for home between Brandon Crawford, who had been anchored at second base, and the inhabitants of the San Francisco Giants dugout, who sprinted to mob him.

headline: Why Samsung Abandoned Its Galaxy Note 7 Flagship Phone
text: When several Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones spontaneously exploded in August, the South Korean company went into overdrive. It urged hundreds of employees to quickly diagnose the problem.

headline: Refugee’s Capture in Germany Is Said to Thwart Terrorist Attack
text: BERLIN — A major terrorist attack on a transportation hub in Germany was narrowly averted, the head of the country’s domestic intelligence agency said on Tuesday, after a 22-year-old Syrian refugee was arrested and more than three pounds of dangerous explosives was found at his home.

headline: How to Get a Good Deal on Flight Upgrades
text: For value-conscious travelers, flying business or first class is increasingly within the realm of possibility. Prices for these seats are lower than in the past, said George Hobica, the founder of the air travel advice site airfarewatchdog.com. “Airlines used to upgrade passengers to first or business class for free,” he said, “but they’ve stopped doing that and are instead making these tickets more affordable and attainable.” Here, he shares his tips on how to snag a seat in these premium cabins without paying premium prices.

headline: A Grand Tour of Switzerland, Reluctant Son in Tow
text: Most Sunday mornings, throughout my childhood near Geneva, my father would drive me to a spot we had never been before. Switzerland occupies about 16,000 square miles. Squeezed between France, Italy, Liechtenstein, Austria and Germany, it is divided into 26 cantons, each influenced by the country it is closest to. All are both fiercely independent and utterly loyal to the Swiss confederation. We explored much of the region where we lived, and that forged a nomadic spirit that has stayed with me.

text: Updated, 10:51 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: Twitter-Salesforce Talks, Buffett’s Taxes, H.R. Red Flags
text: Even though some of the largest shareholders in Salesforce.com have made it clear that they are against the deal, the company is still in talks to buy Twitter, according to two people involved in the discussions who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Vietnam Arrests Mother Mushroom, a Top Blogger, for Criticizing Government
text: HONG KONG — The authorities in Vietnam said on Tuesday that they had arrested a popular blogger who has criticized the country’s one-party government over politically delicate topics, including a  dump of toxic chemicals that devastated fishing communities and set off protests.

headline: Actually, Many ‘Inner Cities’ Are Doing Great
text: To hear Donald J. Trump tell it, America’s “inner cities” are on fire. They’re “a disaster education-wise, job-wise, safety-wise, in every way possible,” he declared in this week’s presidential debate.

headline: 1891: Parnell’s Funeral In Dublin
text: DUBLIN — Mr. Parnell was buried today [Oct. 11] amid warring elements, and in the presence of an immense assemblage. As a scene of great but suppressed excitement, and of still greater impressiveness, the funeral and its surroundings will never be forgotten by those who witnessed it, and it will long furnish a landmark in history for Ireland.

headline: Reporter Who Wrote of Military-Civilian Clash Says He Can’t Leave Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A well-known Pakistani journalist said on Tuesday that he had been barred from leaving the country, days after he wrote that civilian officials had confronted the military over what they called a failure to act against Islamist groups.

headline: For China’s Leaders, U.S. Election Scandals Make the Case for One-Party Rule
text: BEIJING — The Chinese state news media has already declared a winner in the scandal-stained race for the White House: one-party dictatorship.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 4-10, 2016
text: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: Trumpism After Trump
text: LOS ANGELES — If the United States escapes a disaster Nov. 8, it will have done so narrowly. Donald Trump, a dictator-in-waiting with a brat’s temper and a prig’s scowl, has won the support of tens of millions of Americans. It’s fortunate that we are less than a month from the election because we are running out of words to describe him: this phony, this liar, this blowhard, this cheat, this bully, this misogynist, this demagogue, this predator, this bigot, this bore, this egomaniac, this racist, this sexist, this sociopath. I will not go on. It’s pointless. Everyone knows, not least his supporters.

headline: Daphne Rubin-Vega Sings a Song From ‘Miss You Like Hell’
text: Musical theater has been rough on Daphne Rubin-Vega: She’s played a drug addict (Mimi in “Rent”) and an orphan-turned-prostitute (Fantine in “Les Miserables”). Now, in the new musical “Miss You Like Hell,” Ms. Rubin-Vega portrays another desperate woman on the verge, threatened with deportation from the United States and losing a relationship with her estranged daughter.

headline: Questions for: ‘If I Sleep for an Hour, 30 People Will Die‘

headline: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar in Chinese Prison, Is Given Human Rights Award
text: GENEVA — Two years after the Chinese authorities sentenced the prominent Uighur intellectual Ilham Tohti to life imprisonment for promoting separatism and violence, a Swiss-based foundation awarded him a prestigious human rights prize on Tuesday for his efforts to foster dialogue and understanding.

headline: Notes on Brexit and the Pound
text: The much-hyped severe Brexit recession does not, so far, seem to be materializing – which really shouldn’t be that much of a surprise, because as I warned, the actual economic case for such a recession was surprisingly weak. (Ouch! I just pulled a muscle while patting myself on the back!) But we are seeing a large drop in the pound, which has steepened as it becomes likely that this will indeed be a very hard Brexit. How should we think about this?

headline: California Today: Should You Have More Say Over Megaprojects?

headline: The Great American Stagnation
text: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Putin in Syria: Chechnya All Over Again
text: The difference between Aleppo now and Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, at the turn of the millennium is that Western leaders are at least trying to save the Syrians trapped in the besieged city. A decade and a half ago, there were precious few diplomatic missions for the Chechens. Within months of taking power, Vladimir V. Putin had moved decisively to regain control of Chechnya — which had broken free of Moscow’s control in a brief but nasty war in the mid-1990s — and world leaders mostly just looked on.

headline: Will Brexit Unravel the Peace in Northern Ireland?
text: HAMBURG, Germany — Progress, luckily, is often a self-accelerating force. But what about regression? I’m not alone in worrying about the self-perpetuating cycle of social setbacks; across Europe and America, I encounter more and more people concerned that today’s minor tension or flawed election might become tomorrow’s crisis.

headline: Cubs Lose, but It’s Too Early for Ghosts to Rise
text: Here’s a postseason lesson for opponents of the San Francisco Giants: When Conor Gillaspie shrugs and says that he has no particular idea why he is hitting a ball or where it is going, you are advised to duck.

headline: Celebrating Seamus Heaney’s Legacy, at His Birthplace
text: BELLAGHY, Northern Ireland — “No such thing as innocent bystanding,” the actress Fiona Shaw said, staring fiercely at a group of people on a chilly, heavily misted morning in a farmer’s field here, filled with the sounds of lowing cattle and bird calls. The Irish-born Ms. Shaw was standing on top of a hay-filled trough, reading from Seamus Heaney’s “Mycenae Lookout,” and those words — which Heaney may have meant to refer to Ireland, as much as to Aeschylus’ “Oresteia” — took on a surprising, uneasy resonance when spoken out loud.

headline: Venezuela in a Vise
text: Thousands of people are expected to fan out in protest across Venezuela on Wednesday to demand a referendum for the removal of President Nicolás Maduro: His government has overseen an economic crisis that has decimated livelihoods throughout the country.

headline: Tech Companies Expect Free High-Speed Internet for Poorer Americans to Pay Off Later
text: WASHINGTON — There is an axiom in technology: New products typically go to wealthy customers first, before prices eventually fall to reach the masses.

headline: Chappatte on Donald Trump and Lady Liberty
text: Has he gone too far, at last?

headline: On Sex and Power in the Campaign, From the Women Who Cover It
text: A story from the newsroom.

headline: Al Gore, With Hillary Clinton, Reminds Florida: ‘Every. Single. Vote. Counts.’
text: MIAMI — The guest of honor strolled across the stage — hair slicked back and grayed, no tie — embracing his host, briefly, before looking out on the campaign crowd.

headline: My Life in Pictures: Paula Cooper
text: The gallery owner shares images, and inspirations, from the past five decades.

headline: Conceptual Art’s Most Ardent Fan, 50 Years In
text: Her love affair with minimalism began in the ’60s. From there, she pioneered a neighborhood and changed the art world.

headline: In Spain, Reviving Dishes That Disappeared in 1236
text: “Before, in Córdoba, you could see, hear and even smell our history, but you couldn’t taste it,” says the chef Paco Morales, explaining the inspiration for his new restaurant, Noor. Now, thanks to the 35-year-old Córdoba native, who has worked under Ferran Adrià and Andoni Luis Aduriz, you can eat modernized versions of delicacies that disappeared from the city after the Moors were exiled to Morocco in 1236. Three years of research into his hometown’s culinary past have resulted in three tasting menus, featuring overlooked ingredients like bitter oranges and dishes like maxixe cucumber with mint and shanklish, a type of clotted sheep’s milk cheese; a pudding of pine nuts, spring melon, Saharan sea urchin and fresh oregano; and little cheese pies called furniyya, flavored with carob.

headline: Rutgers’s Move to Big Ten Is a Win-Win Everywhere but the Field
text: Fourth-ranked Michigan amassed 309 yards and scored six touchdowns Saturday in Piscataway, N.J., while holding Rutgers to 6 total yards — the result of one pass completion — on the way to a score of 43-0.

headline: ‘Rocky Horror’ Remake: Is It Time to Go Back to Camp?
text: TORONTO — In the predawn hours of a mid-April night, punky revelers weary from a spirited session of jumps to the left, steps to the right and vigorous pelvic thrusts were scattered on a ballroom floor at Casa Loma, a fearsome Gothic-style castle here. High above the bodies, elevated on a crane, stood a gyrating Laverne Cox, who was dressed in a black gown and an enormous disc-shaped headpiece. Gradually lowered to the ground, Ms. Cox met the path of a virginal couple trying to back away from the weirdness. There she extended a hand, covering a rhinestone-sequined glove, and sang her fateful first line: “How do you do?”

headline: A Choose-Your-Own-Adventure Cake
text: Do you prefer a chocolate malt or brown-butter cheesecake filling? Strawberry or chocolate-fudge frosting? Milk Bar’s well-stacked six-inch party cakes, with their confetti-studded layers, can now be ordered with custom frostings, fillings and crumb decorations. They are shipped frozen for arrival on a Thursday (the Saturday before is the cutoff for ordering): Milk ID customized birthday cake, $60, milkbar.goldbely.com.

headline: For Hindus on Long Island, a New Temple 3 Decades in the Making
text: MELVILLE, N.Y. — With each green chile prepared, the coughing grew louder. The smell, and kick, of Indian spices filled the kitchen air, as the volunteers prepared meals for the weekend.

headline: The Kenneth Bone Effect
text: After the dust from the second presidential debate settled on Monday morning, it turned out that the real sartorial shocker of the night had not been Hillary Clinton’s Ralph Lauren pantsuit or Melania Trump’s pussy-bow Gucci top. It was a red cable-knit cotton sweater with a quarter zip worn by Kenneth Bone, audience member, undecided voter and overnight sensation.

headline: Galaxy Note 7 Abandoned by Customers
text: Consumers put their safety first after Samsung announced that it would stop selling its troubled Galaxy Note 7 smartphone following new reports of the phones catching fire.

headline: Video: 8 Fashion Trends for Spring
text: Exaggerated shoulders, 1980s silhouettes, casual shoes and more trends from New York to Paris fashion weeks.

headline: A Food Hall Lures the Lunch Crowd in Chicago
text: The regional food hall — a kaleidoscope of local, artisanal purveyors that has been well established for decades in cities on the East and West Coasts — has finally made it to Chicago. But what took so long?

headline: The Wisdom Beneath the Steps of ‘Dances at a Gathering’
text: Nobody speaks, is betrayed, dies or goes mad in Jerome Robbins’s ballet “Dances at a Gathering,” but this hourlong, pure-dance work, set to an anthology of Chopin piano pieces, is nonetheless a multilayered masterpiece of theater.

headline: Earth-Rattling Times at Samsung and Twitter
text: Samsung and Twitter are not tech companies whose names are often uttered in the same breath. But they are connected right now by the theme of explosions.

headline: Checking for the Windows 10 Anniversary Update
text: Q. How do I get the Windows 10 Anniversary Update on my PC?

headline: A Caribbean Sun Shines at Sally Roots in Bushwick
text: SALLY ROOTS A sunny taste of the Caribbean — with jerk chicken, skewered shrimp slathered with garlicky mojo, codfish cakes and an array of tropical drinks — is the work of the partners Matthew Maddy, James Freeman and Johnny De Piper. Mr. Maddy is responsible for the look of the space, which includes a central bar and a patio. (The name is based on the label of an old Calypso recording, from Sally Ruth Records, that his grandmother owned.) This being Brooklyn, there’s a kale salad, but here it’s dressed with coconut. And if you fancy a slice of pineapple on your burger, you can have that, too: 195 Wyckoff Avenue (Harman Avenue), Bushwick, Brooklyn, 347-425-0888, sallyroots.com.

headline: Glamour on the Gowanus: Nets Really Call Brooklyn Home
text: Even Jeremy Lin lives in Brooklyn now.

headline: Solving the Riddle of the Slovenian Sphinx and the Pussy Bow
text: It was a relief to see Melania Trump at the St. Louis debate.

headline: Donald Trump Berates Paul Ryan and ‘Disloyal’ Republicans
text: Donald J. Trump lashed out at Speaker Paul D. Ryan and other critics within his party on Tuesday in a barrage of Twitter posts deriding the highest-ranking Republican as a feckless leader and warning that those who have been disloyal risked handing the election to Hillary Clinton.

headline: Court Gives President More Power Over Consumer Agency Chief
text: In a significant blow to the authority of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the agency’s structure was unconstitutional but offered a fairly simple remedy: Give the president the power to fire the agency’s director at will.

headline: Pondicheri
text: An all-day Indian cafe, the first outpost from the Houston chef Anita Jaisinghani.

headline: Pondicheri Makes Indian Flavors an All-Day Affair
text: “This is the first place you’ve taken me where I’d come back and spend my own money,” a friend said in the middle of lunch at Pondicheri. He is highly sensitive to pretension and unjustified expense, so whenever I take him along on one of my hunting parties, I try to pick something with a high ratio of flavor to price. At Pondicheri, I finally hit his sweet spot.

headline: Can the U.S. Really Get Astronauts to Mars by 2030?
text: In an essay published Tuesday on CNN’s website, President Obama renewed his call for American astronauts to visit Mars.

headline: No End in Sight to Strike by Harvard’s Cafeteria Workers Over Wages
text: A dispute over wages and benefits between Harvard and its cafeteria workers has led to a strike that is now in its seventh day, with no immediate resolution in sight, an official at the nation’s wealthiest university said on Tuesday.

headline: Do You Have a Samsung Galaxy Note 7? Here’s What to Do
text: Q. What should I do if I have a Samsung Galaxy Note 7 phone?

headline: Aaron Pryor, Boxing Champion Who Defeated Addiction, Dies at 60
text: Aaron Pryor, whose erratic swings and stances won him the world junior welterweight boxing championship but also mirrored a career-ending struggle with cocaine addiction, died on Sunday at his home in Cincinnati. He was 60.

headline: Fighting for Water
text: Nine indigenous groups gathered in New York City to show solidarity with the Standing Rock protest in North Dakota. They are also urging the city to rename Columbus Day “Indigenous Peoples Day.”

headline: Iconic Fashion for a Good Cause
text: “Today, everyone is kind of a tastemaker; with social media, things have moved so fast, and we talk more and more about ‘it girls,’” says Sofia Bernardin, one-half of the rare vintage and second-hand clothing site RE-SEE. She and her co-founder, Sabrina Marshall, who both defected from the magazine world and launched the Paris-based platform in 2013, are “all about the best of the past, those breakaway moments and collections that changed fashion.”

headline: Gunmen Attack Crowded Shiite Shrine in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gunmen disguised as police officers attacked a Shiite shrine packed with hundreds of worshipers in the Afghan capital late Tuesday, killing at least 14 people and wounding dozens, officials and witnesses reported.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Calls Colin Kaepernick’s National Anthem Protest ‘Dumb’
text: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Supreme Court justice who came under fire recently for lacerating comments about Donald J. Trump, has dropped another eyebrow-raising remark about a different figure in the news: the N.F.L. football player Colin Kaepernick and his protest surrounding the national anthem.

headline: Review: ‘Vice News Tonight,’ on HBO, Is New but No Game Changer
text: The “Tonight” in “Vice News Tonight” — Vice Media’s new weeknight newscast on HBO, which began on Monday — is a promise that the show kind of, sort of, doesn’t really keep.

headline: Newspaper Closes in Hungary, and Hungarians See Government’s Hand
text: BUDAPEST — Roland Baksa, an investigative reporter at Hungary’s largest opposition newspaper, packed up his computer on Friday. The publication’s parent company had announced that it would move offices over the weekend, and the editor in chief had promised pizza on Sunday to celebrate the move.

headline: In Jewelers Row in Philadelphia, Condo Plan Worries Preservationists
text: PHILADELPHIA — Among the oldest diamond districts in the country, the Jewelers Row section of this historic city has been a part of the engagement stories of couples in the region for generations.

headline: Hillary Clinton Is a Frail Failure, Donald Trump Warns, but He ‘Will Protect You’
text: As his campaign battles to stave off defections from within the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump has released a new ad attacking Hillary Clinton as “Dangerous” on foreign policy grounds and portraying her as physically incapable of meeting the demands of the presidency.

headline: ‘Clown Hysteria’ Spreads to Britain
text: LONDON — There was the student who spread terror this week by running across the campus of Brunel University in west London dressed as a killer clown and wielding a chain saw.

headline: Cuba and Curiosity at the New York Film Festival
text: Cuba is a forbidden island no longer. It’s been almost two years since President Obama announced that the United States would normalize relations with Cuba. Regularly scheduled flights are taking off, and now you too can book a room there through Airbnb. A country that has been off limits for 50 years will inevitably lure the curious.

headline: W.H.O. Urges Tax on Sugary Drinks to Fight Obesity
text: The World Health Organization on Tuesday urged countries to impose a tax on sugary drinks to battle the growing obesity epidemic and presented new data on the beneficial health effects of such a tax.
