text: To the Editor:

headline: Explosion Batters Neighborhood in China, Killing 14 and Wounding Nearly 150
text: BEIJING — At least 14 people were killed and nearly 150 wounded when a blast tore apart a neighborhood in a small town in northwestern China on Monday, battering nearby homes, shattering windows and sending residents streaming from the smoking ruins.

headline: A Butcher Adds a Pickle Stand to His Portfolio
text: Jake Dickson’s butcher shop in Chelsea Market now has a sibling: a little shop for pickles and other fermented products, more than 30 of them. Bright containers of everything from standard half-sours to Italian eggplant pickles, mole carrots, pickled eggs and kimchi are set out in containers and tubs on a counter, with toothpicks for sampling. Josh Halter (right), a chef and fermentation fanatic, is in charge of this kiosk. The pickle lineup may rotate, as Mr. Halter would like to add some Japanese and Russian specialties: Dickson’s Fine Brines, Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (West 15th Street), 347-262-8526, dicksonsfarmstand.com.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Humans’ and ‘Rectify’
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: Freed Sailors Recount Years of Torture at the Hands of Somali Pirates
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The crew of the Naham 3, a longline fishing trawler, will never forget the day in 2012 when they disappeared.

headline: Gun Control | Gun Rights: Is Resolution Possible?
text: At a Times Insider event on Tuesday, Oct. 25, four New York Times journalists took part in a discussion about gun control and gun rights. Watch the discussion here — and read through the comments, posted in real-time, by New York Times readers.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte Gets Closer to China, and the Neighbors Notice
text: BEIJING — After unleashing an anti-American tirade in Beijing last week, President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines left some Chinese, who like tightly scripted state visits, wondering if their unpredictable guest could be trusted.

headline: Kenya Spares the Lives of Everyone on Its Death Row
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — With a stroke of his pen, President Uhuru Kenyatta spared the lives of thousands of prisoners on Kenya’s death row on Monday by commuting their sentences to life in prison.

headline: Taking Down Dams and Letting the Fish Flow
text: BANGOR, Me. — Joseph Zydlewski, a research biologist with the Maine Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit of the United States Geological Survey, drifted in a boat on the Penobscot River, listening to a crackling radio receiver. The staccato clicks told him that one of the shad that his team had outfitted with a transmitter was swimming somewhere below.

headline: Russian Sports Official Suspended Over Doping Resigns
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s deputy sports minister, who was suspended after accusations that he had coordinated a doping scheme at the 2014 Winter Olympics, has resigned, the government reported Monday.

headline: Sheikh Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani, Former Emir of Qatar, Dies at 84
text: Sheikh Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani, who as the emir of Qatar for 23 years oversaw its independence from Britain and the rapid modernization of its economy, died on Sunday. He was 84.

headline: N.B.A. Schedule: Here’s What to Watch This Week
text: Finally. It’s back.

headline: Liberals Hope Elizabeth Warren Will Serve as Clinton’s Scrutinizer in Chief
text: Senator Elizabeth Warren delivered a blistering rebuke of Donald J. Trump on Monday, warning him that “nasty women vote” and imploring a crowd to cast ballots for Hillary Clinton.

headline: AARP Sues U.S. Over Rules for Wellness Programs
text: Employers have raced to offer workers a hefty financial incentive to sign up for programs meant to improve their health, submitting personal medical details in the process. But as these programs have spread, so has resistance from employees dubious about sharing that information with employers.

headline: Struggling for an Emmett Till Memorial That Withstands Gunshots
text: Along a secluded gravel road that runs between a riverbank and cotton fields in the Mississippi Delta region, a purple sign marks the area where Emmett Till’s mutilated body was pulled from the Tallahatchie River in the summer of 1955.

headline: TD Ameritrade’s Deal With Scottrade Is a Temporary Fix
text: TD Ameritrade’s $4 billion takeover of Scottrade merely delays the inevitable. Uniting the two American online stockbrokers stacks up financially, because of cost cuts, a tax break and a sale of a banking unit. Income and margins should rise, too. But it still leaves TD Ameritrade and rivals like Charles Schwab facing the longer-term competition of index investing and robo advice.

headline: U.S.-Cuba Health Collaboration
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s in a Name? When It’s ‘Trump Place,’ It’s a Revolt
text: At three large rental buildings emblazoned with gold letters spelling out T-R-U-M-P P-L-A-C-E on the Upper West Side, the lobby rain mats embossed with the same name are being replaced, tenants say. The new versions, they have been told, will proclaim the buildings’ addresses, 140, 160 or 180 Riverside Boulevard.

headline: Home and Work: Kris Kim
text: The shopkeeper’s spare minimalism is consistent, from her New York apartment to her pristine store.

headline: Inside a Designer and Entrepreneur’s Pristine Apartment and Store
text: To be told you are making something out of nothing is to be criticized for being overly dramatic, and yet to make something lovely out of nothing, and with very little dramatic flourish, is a clever skill, and precisely what the entrepreneur Kris Kim does. You cannot recognize the designer behind the loose black T-shirt and flowing black linen pants she is wearing on a recent meeting, and that is how she likes it. In fact, she is the designer, and the pieces are from her label, Moderne, which she sells at her shop and 11-year-old commerce site, La Garçonne, as well as at other retailers. The Moderne line is so simple that inside the company it’s referred to as “the Nothing Label.”

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
text: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Kathleen Kane, Former Pennsylvania Attorney General, Is Sentenced to Prison
text: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — The brief, unlikely political career of Kathleen G. Kane, Pennsylvania’s brightest rising star when she was elected attorney general less than four years ago, came to a humiliating close on Monday when a judge sentenced her to 10 to 23 months in prison for her conviction on charges of perjury and abuse of her office.

headline: At New Jersey Transit, a ‘Culture Change’ Is Called For
text: To the Editor:

headline: German Terrorism Case Highlights Europe’s Security Challenges
text: BERLIN — The warning came to the German security authorities in early September from “our best partners,” as they euphemistically refer to the American intelligence agencies: A terrorist assault might be in the works.

headline: Don’t Drink the Hand Sanitizer
text: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer can be found in schools, offices, restrooms and restaurants and is great for cleaning hands in public places. But most of us would never think of drinking it.

headline: Brace Yourself for a Busy Holiday Season at Airports
text: With Thanksgiving less than a month away, airlines and airports — not to mention savvy travelers — are bracing for what could be a record-setting year-end holiday travel season in the United States.

headline: How to Make Your Holiday Air Travel More Bearable
text: There’s not much that any traveler can do about the crowds and long lines at airports during the holiday season. But there are ways to cope.

headline: A Manhattan Exhibit With Antiquity on the Clock
text: In a Roman mosaic from antiquity, a man on a street studies the sundial atop a tall column. The sun alerts him to hurry if he does not want to be late for a dinner invitation.

headline: A John Zorn Weekend — 10-Hour Marathon Concert Included
text: As far as performance marathons go, the 10 hours of John Zorn’s bagatelles on Saturday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn may not have been the most sprawling. (Taylor Mac’s full day of drag-pop two weeks ago, for one thing, was more than double the length of this Zornfest.)

headline: Calais Jungle, Xi Jinping, European Union: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Review: Ballet With Intricate Geometry, and a Lot of Fun
text: WASHINGTON — When she danced — from the early 1960s to the late ’80s — the ballerina Suzanne Farrell gave people so much else to see that they seldom remarked on her physical wit. And now, after she recently announced that her ballet company would close after the 2017-18 season, humor was the last thing to expect from its latest program.

headline: ‘We Are Ready to Leave’: France Clears Out Calais ‘Jungle’
text: CALAIS, France — Hundreds of migrants, mostly young men from Africa or Afghanistan, lined up in the cold on Monday for buses to take them to temporary housing all over France, as the government set in motion a plan in the port of Calais to clear the sprawling migrant camp known as the Jungle once and for all.

headline: For Gordon Hamilton, a Life of Discovery and Danger
text: The helicopter hovered 30 feet above a fjord in Greenland, a thrumming red speck of human ingenuity in a vast wilderness of rock and ice.

headline: Election Chatter, With Two Weeks to Go
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Least 59 Die as Militants Storm Police College Near Quetta, Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Wielding guns and explosives, three militants killed at least 59 people and wounded 120 at a police training college in southwestern Pakistan late Monday, before security forces, who mobilized outside, seized control of the campus, government officials said.

headline: Unicef Cuts Cost of Vaccine That Protects Against 5 Diseases
text: The United Nations Children’s Fund has made a deal with six vaccine manufacturers that will cut in half the price of a shot that protects children against five diseases, the fund announced last week.

headline: Schubert’s Chilly Winter Journey, Told Two Ways
text: Carnegie Hall presented two performances of Schubert’s dark song cycle “Winterreise” (“Winter’s Journey”) over the past two Sundays.

headline: نهايةُ عقودٍ من تقاليد العائلة المالكة إثر صعودِ نجمِ أميرٍ سعودي
text: وهكذا وضع صعود نجم الأمير بن سلمان نهايةً لعقود من التقاليد التي طالما تمسّكت بها العائلة المالكة، والتي تَعتبر احترام الأقدمية ومشاركة السلطة بين فروع العائلة المالكة قيمًا راسخة. فلم يحدث من قبل في تاريخ المملكة أن استأثر وليّ وليّ العهد، الذي يحتل المرتبة الثانية على قائمة انتظار العرش، بكلّ هذا القدر من النفوذ. وهذه المركزية في السلطة كانت سببًا في إثارة غضب الكثيرين من أقاربه.

headline: Lorenzo Lamas Will Fly You to the Grand Canyon (After He’s Sung)
text: Fans of the actor Lorenzo Lamas can be forgiven for thinking that his latest role might be that of a guy who seduces a woman with one hand and fires a bazooka with the other. El Gallo, after all, sounds like one of the chiseled hotties Mr. Lamas has portrayed in action films like “Snake Eater” and “Bounty Tracker.”

headline: Review: In ‘Alfred Hitchcock: A Brief Life,’ Fear Drives a Master of Suspense
text: “Luck is everything,” Alfred Hitchcock once remarked. “My good luck in life was to be a really frightened person. I’m fortunate to be a coward, to have a low threshold of fear, because a hero couldn’t make a good suspense film.”

headline: As Europe and Asia Hoard Cash, Economists See Echoes of Crisis
text: European and Asian investors have been rushing into the United States bond market, spurred by a global glut of savings that has reached record levels.

headline: MetLife Again Faces Off With Regulators Over Its Too-Big-to-Fail Status
text: WASHINGTON — Three judges at Washington’s federal appeals court on Monday questioned the government’s analysis that led to MetLife’s designation as a “too big to fail” financial company, as the Justice Department appeals a lower court’s decision to strip the insurance giant of that label.

headline: The Big League Prospect Who Became a Mob Hit Man
text: The Buick sedan crawled the Providence streets. The April sky was baby blue, the air pleasant and cool. Perfect baseball weather. The man hunched in the back seat once lived for days like this.

headline: Fearing Trump, Bar Association Stifles Report Calling Him a ‘Libel Bully’
text: WASHINGTON — Alarmed by Donald J. Trump’s record of filing lawsuits to punish and silence his critics, a committee of media lawyers at the American Bar Association commissioned a report on Mr. Trump’s litigation history. The report concluded that Mr. Trump was a “libel bully” who had filed many meritless suits attacking his opponents and had never won in court.

headline: 35 Turks With Diplomatic Passports Seek Asylum in Germany
text: BERLIN — Germany has received nearly three dozen applications for political asylum from Turkish diplomats and their families, amid widespread purges of assumed opponents of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, following the failed attempt to overthrow his government, an official said Monday.

headline: Donald Trump Dismisses Latest Accuser: ‘Oh, I’m Sure She’s Never Been Grabbed Before’
text: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — Donald J. Trump on Monday disparaged the latest woman to accuse him of touching her inappropriately, dismissing her as a “porn star” and saying sarcastically, “Oh, I’m sure she’s never been grabbed before.”

headline: Geno Smith Has Torn Knee Ligament; Jets Turn to Ryan Fitzpatrick Again
text: If this were another team, in another season, Monday’s news that a starting quarterback had sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament might be considered an unfortunate setback.

headline: Clinton, Warren, Cubs: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Too Good to Be Ignored: Women Who Reached the Top in Sports
text: When AnnMaria De Mars was growing up in the 1960s and ’70s in Alton, Ill., a “short, fat little kid with real thick glasses,” as she described herself, there were few outlets for girls interested in sports. “Back then, Title IX hadn’t passed, so it was perfectly legal to say, ‘Girls can’t do this,’” she said. Nonetheless, her mother dropped her off at a local Y.M.C.A., with instructions to find an activity. “The options were swimming or sprinting,” Dr. De Mars recalled, and, thanks to one sympathetic instructor, judo.

headline: Women Are Drinking as Much as Men
text: More men than women use and abuse alcohol, but the gender gap is narrowing.

headline: Could Hillary Clinton Win Texas? Some Democrats Say Maybe
text: SILSBEE, Tex. — The last time a Democrat won Texas in a presidential election was 1976, when voters chose Jimmy Carter over Gerald R. Ford. Carey Georgas was 22 back then, a disillusioned Democrat who voted for Eugene McCarthy, the independent candidate, and who was working at Cravens Insurance in this East Texas town.

headline: Bobby Vee, Pop Idol Known for ‘Take Good Care of My Baby,’ Dies at 73
text: Bobby Vee, who became a teenage idol in the early 1960s with infectious hits like “Take Good Care of My Baby” and “The Night Has a Thousand Eyes,” died on Monday in Rogers, Minn. He was 73.

headline: U.N. Addresses Cholera Crisis in Haiti
text: The United Nations has proposed a $400 million aid package, including cash payments to victims.

headline: Why AT&T Isn’t Sweating the Breakup Fee in Its Time Warner Deal
text: AT&T’s chief executive, Randall L. Stephenson, has been pretty casual about the costs of failing to push through the telecommunication giant’s proposed purchase of Time Warner.

headline: Remembering Gordon Hamilton – An Edge-Pushing Prober of Eroding Ice
text: Pushing the frontiers of science on tough questions is hard enough. But doing so when the effort requires research teams to face deadly hazards at the ends of the Earth takes things to another level.

headline: Cuba in All Its Natural Glory at the American Museum of Natural History
text: It won’t be the old car or the thousands of tobacco leaves or even the leaping crocodile model that will greet visitors when they walk into “¡Cuba!,” the first major exhibition the American Museum of Natural History has ever organized about that island nation.

headline: With AT&T-Time Warner Deal Brewing, a Focus on Preserving CNN’s Integrity
text: In its 130-year history, AT&T has transitioned from a telegraph service to a wireless provider to a global communications behemoth.

headline: Discovering Contemporary African Art, With a Curator as a Guide
text: For art to reach you, someone has to find it and believe that you need to see it. Someone like Bisi Silva, Hannah O’Leary or Kevin Dumouchelle, curators and specialists who are discovering, and showing to the world, the contemporary art of Africa.

headline: Some Health Plan Costs to Increase by an Average of 25 Percent, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — Premiums for midlevel health plans under the Affordable Care Act will increase by an average of 25 percent next year, while consumers in some states will find significantly fewer insurance companies offering coverage, the federal government said Monday.

headline: Art Dealers Move Out of the Gallery and Into a Taco Bell
text: Stefania Bortolami still recalls, with cathartic exultation, the moment she decided to display her art in a slower, smaller way. It was May 2015, and Ms. Bortolami, the owner of the Bortolami Gallery in Manhattan, was at the art fair Frieze New York — her sixth such gathering of the year.

headline: AT&T-Time Warner Deal Is a Shot in the Dark
text: The official rationale for AT&T’s $85 billion deal to purchase Time Warner is that in uncertain times, bigger is better.

headline: A Wedding Night Upgrade at the Plaza
text: Dear Diary:

headline: How an Aesthete’s Eye Can Help a Doctor’s Hand
text: For eight years, Bonnie Pitman has been battling a rare, incurable lung infection. Frequent hospitalizations took such a toll on her that she had to step down from her dream job as director of the Dallas Museum of Art, and she uses a breathing apparatus to open her airways several times a day.

headline: Consultant With Ties to Donald Trump Linked to Offer to Hide Source of Donations
text: A video posted on Monday by a British newspaper appeared to show a Republican consultant with ties to Donald J. Trump offering to disguise the source of contributions to a “super PAC” intended to aid Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign.

headline: Letters on U.N.’s Response to Cholera in Haiti
text: Read the report from Philip Alston, a special United Nations human rights adviser, to the deputy secretary general Jan Eliasson, and Mr. Eliasson's response.

headline: Code Names and Covert Meetings in AT&T’s Courtship of Time Warner
text: Soon after the wheels of the Time Warner private jet touched down at Dallas Love Field airport on Oct. 11, the media titan’s chief executive, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, and his top lieutenants cautiously made their way to the meeting room of a nearby hangar.

headline: Voters Increasingly Turning to Internet for Information, Survey Shows
text: Voters have stepped away from the television and are digesting the presidential and Senate races through the internet, a new poll of persuadable voters in five Senate battleground states shows.

headline: A Chilly Reaction to AT&T-Time Warner Deal
text: The $85 billion AT&T deal for Time Warner won’t win regulatory approval. We will continue our current course even if it does. Will a line of major media consolidation dominoes — involving titans like Disney, Fox and Comcast — begin to fall? Not likely.

headline: Cleveland Indians Fans Hope That Ghosts of Past Are Put to Rest
text: “Hello, Sid Monge,” Ralph calls.

headline: Justice Dept. Shakes Up Inquiry Into Eric Garner Chokehold Case
text: The Justice Department has replaced the New York team of agents and lawyers investigating the death of Eric Garner, officials said, a highly unusual shake-up that could jump-start the long-stalled case and put the government back on track to seek criminal charges.

headline: Obama Urges Democrats to Turn Out in Force Against Donald Trump and G.O.P.
text: SAN DIEGO — President Obama portrayed Donald J. Trump as a threat to the survival of the republic on Monday as he beseeched Democrats to repudiate the Republican nominee and his message by turning out in large numbers to elect Hillary Clinton and sweep a tide of Republicans out of office.

headline: Next Job for Obama? Silicon Valley Is Hiring
text: WASHINGTON — Staring intently at the dual screens inside a flight simulator this month at the University of Pittsburgh, President Obama tapped the controls in front of him, firing faux thrusters as he pretended to maneuver his space shuttle toward the International Space Station. Pulse up. Pulse to the right. Left. Down. Down. Left. Left.

headline: Once a Die-Hard Cubs Fan, Jason Kipnis Is Now Trying to Extend Their Misery
text: CLEVELAND — When Jason Kipnis was a boy, long before he helped the Cleveland Indians earn a spot in the World Series, he attended St. Norbert School, 21 miles from Wrigley Field.

headline: LeBron James Remains a Rock Amid N.B.A.’s Changing Terrain
text: CLEVELAND — Great change, as it often does, swept through the N.B.A. during the off-season. It came in the form of the draft and trades and signings. Kevin Durant relocated to the Bay Area. Dwyane Wade went home to Chicago. Joakim Noah and Derrick Rose moved to New York.

headline: Promises, Promises From AT&T
text: AT&T’s $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner would transform it from a landline, wireless and satellite TV company into one of the most important media gatekeepers in the country, giving it a strong financial incentive to use its programming to hammer competitors.

headline: Turkey Barges Into the Mosul Fight
text: It’s been clear from the start that the American and Iraqi-led battle to retake Mosul from the Islamic State presented a logistical and strategic puzzle — even a possible nightmare — in which the interests of multiple countries and sectarian groups had to be reconciled and their roles carefully coordinated. Without such coordination, the effort to defeat ISIS and liberate thousands of Mosul residents who have suffered horribly under the terrorist group for two years would be severely undermined.

headline: World Series Preview: For Cubs or Indians, Decades of Waiting Are Nearly Over
text: It might as well be a matchup from a movie: the two teams with the longest title droughts in baseball paired in the same World Series. No wonder, then, that Joe Maddon has watched “Field of Dreams” since his Chicago Cubs clinched the National League pennant.

headline: Vatican to Act as Mediator Between Venezuela’s Dueling Sides
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — As President Nicolás Maduro flew to Rome for a hastily arranged meeting with Pope Francis, representatives of Venezuela’s government and a leader of the opposition agreed on Monday to allow the Vatican to mediate a dialogue intended to solve the country’s political crisis.

headline: Seeking Senate Majority, Cuomo Tries New Tactic: Stumping for Democrats
text: ALBANY — In 2014, while cruising to re-election, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s efforts to help his fellow Democrats were, to be polite, understated.

headline: Soldiers Struggling to Repay Enlistment Bonuses Issued in Error
text: After 21 years in the military, three deployments, and a roadside bomb blast that left him bleeding and unconscious, Christopher Van Meter got a letter from the Pentagon saying he improperly received enlistment bonuses and now owed the government $46,000.

headline: Cubs, Loaded With Talent, May Get Kyle Schwarber Back, Too
text: CLEVELAND — On Monday, a day before the Chicago Cubs were to open the World Series against the Cleveland Indians at Progressive Field, team officials keenly watched the at-bats of Kyle Schwarber on live video feeds from Arizona.

headline: Yankees Plan Stadium Changes to Fight Attendance Drop
text: In an effort to stem plummeting attendance, the Yankees on Monday announced several changes to Yankee Stadium, including a play area for children and open-air patio bars. The enhancements aim to draw younger fans who have increasingly abandoned the team in recent years.

headline: Arian Foster, Worn Down by Injuries, Announces Immediate Retirement
text: Arian Foster, a four-time Pro Bowler who was among the league’s top rushers in 2014, became the latest football player to leave the sport because of injuries, abruptly announcing his retirement on Monday after playing in only four games this season.

headline: Ex-Aide Says Christie Had ‘Memory Issue’ About Bridge Lane Closings
text: NEWARK — In December 2013, Bridget Anne Kelly began to feel she was in “an alternate universe.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Harvest,’ a Crisis of Feeling for Young Evangelicals
text: Context is not everything when it comes to our experience of theater, but it’s not nothing, either. “The Harvest,” a new play by Samuel D. Hunter about a group of young evangelical missionaries in Idaho, has a serious context problem. These idealistic young Christians, all in their 20s, are heading off to save souls in a place referred to only as “the Middle East.”

headline: Review: In ‘A Life,’ Lonely and Looking to the Stars for Answers
text: A great fear of single urbanites comes unhappily true for the central character in “A Life,” a bleak new play by Adam Bock that opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons. David Hyde Pierce stars as a 54-year-old gay man living in New York who has recently been dumped by his boyfriend — although that’s not the great fear I referred to.

headline: Offer at a Pub
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If I had to guess the concept behind John E. Bennett’s third New York Times crossword just by looking at the completed grid, I would have put money on it being called “Something About Drunken Pandas.” That’s what it looks like to me. The black squares look like a panda bear and there is alcohol all over its face.

headline: Report Highlights How Guns Flow Into New York From States With Weaker Laws
text: The .40-caliber pistol used to kill a New York City police officer last year was bought in South Carolina on Feb. 28, 2008.

headline: U.N. Plans to Pay Victims of Cholera Outbreak It Caused in Haiti
text: UNITED NATIONS — Ever since United Nations peacekeepers introduced a devastating cholera epidemic to Haiti in 2010, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has insisted that the global body is immune from legal claims. In the past few months, he has acknowledged a “moral responsibility” for the epidemic, but he has stopped short of saying sorry.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “If we’re successful, it’s the beginning of the end of the war on marijuana.”

headline: Is This Election Rigged Against Trump?
text: With Donald J. Trump's claims that the election is rigged against him, we take a look at past close and contentious elections.

headline: Resettling China’s ‘Ecological Migrants’
text: Miaomiao Lake Village is just one of the new communities built to accommodate the world’s largest environmental migration project. But residents are struggling to adapt.

headline: Calais Jungle, Mosul, Clinton: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Corrections: October 25, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Finding Dory’ and ‘The Adam Ruins Everything Election Special’
text: In “Finding Dory,” Ellen DeGeneres is back as the blue tang sidekick to everyone’s favorite clown fish, Nemo. And Adam Conover ruins everything you thought you knew about presidential politics.

headline: After Egypt’s Revolution, a New Start in American Exile
text: When a young Egyptian medical student’s dreams of democracy collapsed, he joined fellow expatriates in the United States, documenting their hopes for the future.

headline: Don’t Lock ’Em Up. Give ’Em a Chance to Quit Drugs.
text: By the time the police found him smoking crack in a Seattle parking garage one afternoon in late 2013, Roland Vasquez had been arrested more than two dozen times. Once a paralegal in his hometown, San Antonio, Vasquez says he started using drugs about 16 years ago after helping to negotiate bail for a dealer — and receiving a half-pound of heroin as a “thank you.” A father of three young children, he moved to Seattle in the mid-2000s to be closer to his own dad and farther from the people who got him hooked. But his cravings soon overwhelmed him, and he resigned himself to cycling between jail and the streets.

headline: Your Facts or Mine?
text: “Obama to Declare MARTIAL LAW If Trump Wins Election.” That was the teaser text that recently popped up on my Facebook news feed. It directed me to a post from a page called Nation in Distress, one of the many hyperpartisan Facebook pages that have gained in popularity this year.

headline: The Unhappy Warriors
text: Gail Collins: Two weeks, Arthur, two weeks! I’m not sure what the world will be like when this election is over. Unless, of course, we’re defending ourselves against a mutiny from the right, the revolt of Donald’s Deplorables. Although he doesn’t really strike me as a guy who has much taste for the barricades. What do you think of all the “rigged election” drama?

headline: North Carolina’s Noxious Pig Farms
text: The landscape of eastern North Carolina is dotted with giant pools of bright pink sludge. These are waste lagoons, where industrial farms across the state dispose of billions of gallons of untreated pig urine and feces every year.

headline: The Cubs Reach the Promised Land. Now What?
text: Chicago — I went to my first Chicago Cubs game in 1975, over the objections of my father, who said a Cubs fan, coming to believe in the futility of human endeavor, will have a sad life.

headline: The Epidemic of Worry
text: We’ve had a tutorial on worry this year. The election campaign isn’t really about policy proposals, issue solutions or even hope. It’s led by two candidates who arouse gargantuan anxieties, fear and hatred in their opponents.

headline: Dear Republican Voters ...
text: You are a Republican.

headline: Is Trump Right About Putin?
text: Should the United States be less hawkish toward Russia?

headline: The Problem for Women Is Not Winning. It’s Deciding to Run.
text: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York first decided she wanted to be a senator when she was 7 or 8. Two decades later, as a law firm associate, she went to an event featuring the first lady, Hillary Clinton, and heard her speech as a personal call to public service.

headline: Dreamworld Theme Park Accident Kills 4, Australian Officials Say
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Four people were killed on Tuesday when a raft in an amusement park’s white-water attraction flipped over, trapping them in the ride’s machinery, the authorities said.

headline: After Egypt’s Revolution, a New Start in American Exile
text: I was a medical student and political activist when the revolution against the Mubarak regime in Egypt broke out in 2011. While studying in Alexandria, I assisted as a medic during clashes between demonstrators and government forces. A few days before the fall of Mubarak, a young man was shot dead while standing between my friend Hesham and me. We could not save him.

headline: Smashing Pumpkins
text: Do you like this time of year in general, and Halloween in particular? What do you like to do to celebrate the season and the holiday?

headline: Questions for: ‘After 108 Years of Unfulfilled Yearning, Cubs Fans Are Taking Nothing for Granted’
text: Article: “After 108 Years of Unfulfilled Yearning, Cubs Fans Are Taking Nothing for Granted”

headline: Six Centuries of Madness: An Asylum’s History
text: THIS WAY MADNESS LIESThe Asylum and BeyondBy Mike JayIllustrated. 255 pp. Thames & Hudson. $45.

headline: Obama Brought Silicon Valley to Washington
text: This October, the White House opened its doors to a few thousand people for South by South Lawn, a daylong event described as a “festival of ideas, art and action.” Both the event and its name were a nod to South by Southwest, the annual technology-and-music festival held in Austin, Tex., where Barack and Michelle Obama showed up as surprise keynote speakers earlier this year. The story goes that they were so impressed by their experiences, they decided to host their own microrendition before leaving office. Attendees at the White House version — the types of people who describe themselves in Twitter bios as “creator” or “innovator” — were told to dress casually, in clothes suitable for a picnic. The D.J. Beverly Bond, of Black Girls Rock, blasted Public Enemy’s anthem “Fight the Power” and Parliament’s “Flash Light” across the lawn, which was studded with coffee carts, Lego sculptures and virtual-reality stations. Enormous stages erected for the occasion housed a rotating cast of musical guests and speakers throughout the afternoon. As the sun began to set, volunteers handed out plaid blankets so people could stretch out on the ground.

headline: From ‘Hamilton’ to Donald Trump: Are All ‘Grievances’ Created Equal?
text: At the climax of the Broadway musical “Hamilton,” Aaron Burr and Alexander Hamilton exchange a series of increasingly hostile letters in the song “Your Obedient Servant.” Burr enumerates a litany of perceived insults: Hamilton has called him “amoral” and “a dangerous disgrace” and blocked his political aspirations. “Burr, your grievance is legitimate,” Hamilton replies dismissively. “I stand by what I said, every bit of it/You stand only for yourself/It’s what you do/I can’t apologize because it’s true.” An outraged Burr feels he has been doubly wronged — first he is bad-mouthed and then his complaint is answered with a shrug. These irreconcilable differences came to a head on July 11, 1804, in a fatal duel in Weehawken, N.J.

headline: Omarosa Manigault Changed Parties for Trump
text: You’re a prominent member of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign, as the director of African-American outreach, after competing on “The Apprentice” in 2004. Statistically speaking, he does not seem to be having very much success with either women or minorities. Oh, my God, I disagree. When I took the position, we were polling at zero. Nationally, we’re at an average of 8 percent. Romney and McCain got around 6 to 7 percent of the African-American vote. Our goal is to get 15 to 20 percent of the African-American vote, and we still think that number is possible.

headline: Who Do You Want to Win the 2016 Presidential Election?
text: The presidential primaries, party conventions and televised debates are all over. In fact, early voting is already underway in many states. With only two weeks left until Election Day, we’re in the homestretch of what The Times has called “the most surreal presidential campaign in modern times.”

headline: New True-Crime Books for Fall
text: Not all true-crime books are created equal. Some explore the criminal mind. Others focus on the lives of the victims. And then there are the ones that look beyond the crime to the historical period and social conditions in which it’s rooted. But one thing can be said for them all: True crime is hardly ever boring.

headline: Voters Fear Their Ballot Won’t Count, Poll Shows
text: Fewer than half of Americans are very confident that their vote for president will be counted correctly — and most say their ballot will not matter anyway because the political process is so dominated by corporate interests.

headline: For Iran, Exerting Force While Making Nice Is Part of the Plan
text: TEHRAN — Just as conservative opponents of the nuclear deal with Iran had warned, Tehran seems to be moving aggressively to expand its regional influence while working to counter American interests throughout the Middle East.

headline: A.I. Inspiration: The Science Fiction That Frames Discussion
text: WASHINGTON — Science fiction comes up often in serious discussions about artificial intelligence and weapons. That is partly a reflection of current technological limits and the deep concerns that surround the development of thinking machines that can kill. Here is a selection of some of the works that are most often mentioned:

headline: The Golden State Warriors Play the Beautiful Game
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — There was a span on Friday night, barely more than a minute, when Golden State Warriors forward Kevin Durant drained 3-pointers on three straight possessions against the Portland Trail Blazers. It was just an N.B.A. preseason game, but the check-your-phone-and-miss-it sequence sent the home crowd into a full-throated frenzy and made all the postgame highlights.

headline: The Pentagon’s ‘Terminator Conundrum’: Robots That Could Kill on Their Own
text: CAMP EDWARDS, Mass. — The small drone, with its six whirring rotors, swept past the replica of a Middle Eastern village and closed in on a mosque-like structure, its camera scanning for targets.

headline: ‘I Had a Scary Dream About Donald Trump’: Muslim Parents Face a Tense Election
text: Bilal Elcharfa was pouring cereal for his children before school this month when his 7-year-old daughter, Maaria, walked into the kitchen, calling for him.

headline: Syngenta Warns of Delay in Takeover by ChemChina
text: LONDON — Syngenta said on Tuesday that its takeover by the state-owned China National Chemical Corporation could be delayed until early 2017, as European authorities take a deeper look at a wave of deals among the biggest producers of seeds and chemicals designed to protect crops.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Election Season, Hotel Packages
text: Whether you’re a Democrat, a Republican or an independent, or just looking to get away from anything related to the presidential election, hotels around the country have you covered with special packages. Some offers are valid only for election night, Nov. 8, while others are also available for a few days before and after the event or up until Inauguration Day, Jan. 20.

headline: Is It Harder to Write Humorously Than It Is to Write Seriously?
text: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Rivka Galchen discuss the difficulty in writing funny.

headline: A New Trump Brand Not Named for Trump? Yes, Meet Scion
text: The new line from Trump Hotels won’t bear the famous name behind the original brand, but that was the plan all along, according to its chief executive.

headline: Self-Driving Truck’s First Mission: A 120-Mile Beer Run
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The futurists of Silicon Valley may not have seen this one coming: The first commercial delivery made by a self-driving truck was 2,000 cases of Budweiser beer.

headline: The Italian Winemakers’ Cult
text: It was a hot, late summer evening in Tuscan wine country — and, unexpectedly, I was getting a lesson in astrology.

headline: New York Today: Foliage in Full Force
text: Updated, 8:14 a.m.

headline: Militants Bomb Kenya Hotel, Killing 12; Shabab Claim Responsibility
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Islamist militants struck a hotel in northern Kenya on Tuesday morning, killing a dozen people and stoking outrage from Kenyans who accused their government of not doing enough to protect them from a relentless menace.

headline: Morning Agenda: A New Media Order, Crisis Echos, MetLife Disputes Its Status
text: Lily and Rabbit met in secret to discuss Bobtail, lest details were leaked.

headline: Third Heathrow Airport Runway Backed by British Government
text: LONDON — After decades of delay, the British government endorsed the expansion of London’s Heathrow Airport on Tuesday. The decision to build a third runway at the airport provoked a ferocious response that illustrated why a succession of politicians have ducked the issue since the 1970s.

headline: Should the Food Industry Sneak Vegetables Into Food?
text: Puréed spinach in brownies. “Red velvet” pancakes made from beets. Oatmeal cookies with cauliflower bits. There are hundreds of creative ways to sneak fruits and vegetables past the wrinkled noses of even the pickiest children.

headline: Pakistan Reels After Attack on Police Training College Leaves 61 Dead
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan was reeling on Tuesday from a major terrorist attack: an overnight assault on a police training college in the southwest that officials said had killed at least 61 people, most of them cadets.

headline: As ID Laws Fall, Voters See New Barriers Rise
text: MADISON, Wis. — It seemed a clear victory for voting rights advocates in July when a federal court invalidated much of Wisconsin’s restrictive elections law, concluding that it discriminated against minorities by requiring voters to produce photo identification cards that blacks and Latinos too often lack. The remedy was straightforward: Henceforth, the state was to “promptly issue a credential valid as a voting ID to any person” who applied for one.

headline: Word + Quiz: serenity
News Quiz | Oct. 18-24, 2016
text: Last week’s quiz must have been particularly difficult, because there were only two questions — one about Bob Dylan, and another about the Islamic State — that 90 percent or more of you got right.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa and the Reason Not to Buy Into the ‘See Now/Shop Now’ Movement
text: Perhaps the most convincing argument yet against the “see now/shop now” movement that threw the most recent women’s wear season into chaos occurred Sunday afternoon in Paris, almost three weeks after the season had officially ended. It took the form of Azzedine Alaïa’s spring collection, which could be termed “see when it’s ready/shop later.”

headline: Clinton Leads by 7 Points in North Carolina Poll
text: A new poll, in line with other recent ones, shows the crucial battleground state is looking far less like a tossup than it did weeks ago.

text: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: California Today: A One-Woman Lifeline for Eureka’s Homeless
text: Good morning.

headline: The ‘Saddest’ Polar Bear Lives in a Mall in China
text: BEIJING — In a shopping mall in southern China, a polar bear named Pizza paces past murals of icebergs in his glass enclosure. He shakes his shaggy head under artificial lights. He crouches by an air vent to sniff the outside world.

headline: What Do Trump and Marx Have in Common?
text: HAMBURG, Germany — We have a word in German, “Wutbürger,” which means “angry citizen” — though like many German compound words, its meaning can never quite be captured in a pithy English translation. And yet nothing in either language quite frames this current political moment.

headline: ‘The Worst We Have Ever Seen’: Fewer Migrants, More Death
text: GENEVA — The harrowing journey across the Mediterranean from North Africa to Europe has become increasingly deadly for asylum seekers desperate to find a better life.

headline: Trevor Noah: The First Time I Drove a Car. (I Was 6.)
text: When I was 5 years old, we moved to Eden Park, a neighborhood adjacent to several black townships on the outskirts of Johannesburg — half-colored and half-black, my mother figured, like us. It was me and her, alone. There was this sense of the two of us embarking on a grand adventure. We weren’t just mother and son. We were a team.

headline: Pizzas, Pony Rides and Dolphin Shows: Balms for North Korea’s Elite
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea — Towering apartment blocks line the gleaming, six-lane avenue known as Future Scientists Street, their boldly colored facades leaping from the drab hues that dominate the rest of Pyongyang’s skyline.

headline: More Migrants Leave Calais ‘Jungle’ Camp as Demolition Begins
text: CALAIS, France — Young men with scarves wrapped around their faces to ward off the morning cold and with bags and suitcases in tow continued to trickle out of the migrant camp near the French port of Calais on Tuesday, the second day of a long-awaited operation to clear it out.

headline: Monte dei Paschi to Cut Jobs and Close Branches in Turnaround Bid
text: LONDON — Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the beleaguered Italian lender, said on Tuesday that it would slash jobs, close branches and sell some businesses as it seeks to convince investors to back its plan to raise new capital.

headline: Challenging Boundaries With Her Naked Body
text: Carolee Schneemann’s influence, both acknowledged and unacknowledged, is widespread, and the artist documents this beautifully in a binder she has kept for 20 years called “Influence, Plagiarism, I Forgot.” It juxtaposes her work with images she comes across in art and pop culture, and last month it was all printed as a magazine by the Artist’s Institute in New York.

headline: No Vacancies in California? Housing Report Begs to Differ
text: Vacant lots in the state, most of them in San Francisco or Los Angeles, could accommodate some 225,000 homes and apartments, a report says.

headline: Brock Osweiler Shows Broncos They’re Better Off Without Him
text: The Denver Broncos were an unusual Super Bowl champion last season because they won without top-level quarterback play.

headline: Eight Sleek, Portable Speakers
text: Compact designs make it easier than ever to travel with tunes.

headline: AT&T Cheerleading Squad for Merger: Nearly 100 Lobbyists
text: WASHINGTON — From the political right and the left, AT&T’s $85 billion bid for Time Warner has provoked pushback. But AT&T, in addition to its billions of dollars of capital, has another arsenal at its disposal: one of the most formidable lobbying operations in Washington.

headline: Harvard Reaches Tentative Agreement to End Cafeteria Workers’ Strike
text: Cafeteria workers at Harvard, who have been on strike for nearly three weeks in an effort to avoid an increase in their health care costs and to earn higher salaries, could return to work this week after a tentative agreement was reached with the university, a union president said.

headline: 1916: Great Attack At Verdun Inflicts Big Defeat on Prince
text: France’s magnificent Verdun army has inflicted signal defeat on the Crown Prince’s forces in a brilliant offensive on the right bank of the Meuse.

text: Norma Desmond is ready for her close-up. Again.

headline: What Drives Donald Trump? Fear of Losing Status, Tapes Show
text: By any measure, Arsenio Hall was a Hollywood success: He had starred in popular films, packed houses as a stand-up comic and hosted a hit late-night television show bearing his name.

headline: The Beatrice Inn
text: Angie Mar, the chef and owner, has transformed this West Village restaurant into a meat lover’s palace like no other.

headline: At the Beatrice Inn, Cuisine for Animals
text: The last time I reviewed the Beatrice Inn, the going was tough. Formerly a nightclub that reliably infuriated its neighbors in the West Village, the place had just been rehabilitated by new owners, including the magazine editor Graydon Carter, who envisioned a chophouse of old-establishment sensibilities.

headline: If Immigration Can’t Be Stopped, Maybe It Can Be Managed
text: Can anything be done about illegal immigration?

headline: Review: Jake Gyllenhaal Shines in a Joyous ‘Sunday in the Park With George’
text: Jake Gyllenhaal, you’ll be delighted to hear, can speak pointillism. Even more to the, uh, point, he can sing pointillism, which isn’t easy at all. It involves concentration and balance and order, not to mention being able to summon all those radiant flecks of color and light.

headline: The Enticing Power of Highly Plucked Brows
text: There is a pervasive myth that all women are born with caterpillar-like brows that we then destroy by our own hand. An online meme reads, “This could be us” — over a photo of a woman with gorgeous, prominent brows — “but we had tweezers in the 8th grade.” Not true: My own have always been thin and ashy blond. For the past two years, since the return of the power brow, I have tried willing them to grow via prayer and several tubes of $95 serum, the second ingredient of which was castor oil. I did not emerge looking like Cara Delevingne.

headline: Spain Moves From Deadlock to Gridlock
text: For 10 months, Spain has been plodding along with a caretaker government. That could end this weekend now that the Socialist Party has finally agreed to let Mariano Rajoy, head of the conservative Popular Party, be formally named prime minister. Whether that means that better times lie ahead for Spain remains to be seen.

headline: A Classic Thanksgiving Dinner Menu
text: Timeless Thanksgiving recipes from NYT Cooking for a holiday feast to serve 10 to 12 guests.

headline: Ex-Nurse Charged With Killing 8 Nursing Home Residents in Ontario
text: OTTAWA — There were few common threads in the lives of the eight nursing home patients, who ranged in age from 75 to 96. One owned a tool and die shop; another was a factory worker. Some were pillars of churches; many were parents.

headline: I Was Never Jackie Chan, and I’m Not Jeremy Lin
text: For a long time, playing pickup basketball as an Asian-American guy involved the considerable likelihood that someone would call you Yao Ming.

headline: Six Modern Mexican Design Studios to Watch
text: When it comes to objects for the home, it’s easy to associate Mexico with its rich tradition of local handicrafts: the boldly colored blankets, the lace, the ceramics, the embroidery. And at the eighth annual Design Week Mexico, which took place this month in the country’s capital, a steadily growing crop of young up-and-coming Mexican studios elevated the same traditional techniques and local materials for a more global scene. Here are six to watch.

headline: A Project Mends a Gash in the Street Grid of Washington
text: WASHINGTON — The depressed highway is a road from nowhere, the remnant of an Interstate once planned to cut through residential neighborhoods. Activists blocked the larger plan for the freeway in the 1960s, so this small segment close to the Capitol is left to feed traffic from city streets to other freeways, leading south over the Potomac to Virginia and east across the Anacostia River.

headline: A Quick Guide to Rising Obamacare Rates
text: The Obama administration released the prices for many Obamacare health plans on Monday, and they showed big increases in many parts of the country. Obamacare customers will begin shopping for new plans next week, just a few days before the presidential election.

headline: The 8 friends you make in the modern workplace
text: Work friends are, if not essential to survival in the office, at least essential to enjoying the office.

headline: Seizing on Rising Costs, Trump Says Health Law Is ‘Over’
text: Donald J. Trump, desperate for a winning political issue in the final two weeks of the presidential race, fiercely attacked Hillary Clinton on Tuesday over sharp premium increases that will hit some Americans covered under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: The Funfetti Explosion
text: When Candace Nelson opened the first Sprinkles bakery in Los Angeles in 2005, she did not actually have any sprinkles on hand. “I liked the word, but I thought of them as a supermarket pick, waxy and fake,” she said. “Not elegant, chic and modern.”

headline: Prince’s Paisley Park Is Cleared to Open as a Museum
text: Paisley Park, Prince’s storied recording lair outside Minneapolis, has finally cut through the red tape to become a museum.

headline: Why Does Fall Foliage Turn So Red and Fiery? It Depends.
text: Leaves scream their final cries in color before dropping to the ground. Their shouts — in golden, crimson or scarlet — eventually fade to brown bellows, and their lifeless bodies dry up on the forest floor. It absorbs their crinkly corpses and that’s it — worm food. The fall of a leaf in autumn is an orchestrated death. A complex, brilliant, beautiful death.

headline: John John Florence Clinches His First World Surfing Title
text: The surfing world knew John John Florence was the best. On Tuesday, he made it official.

headline: Mosul Fight Unleashes New Horrors on Civilians
text: ERBIL, Iraq — As security forces bear down on Mosul, the Islamic State has moved hundreds of civilians from villages around the city to use as human shields, and the United Nations said the militants may have killed nearly 200 people. To the east, near the Kurdish-controlled city of Kirkuk, Sunni Arabs who fled there to escape violence are being forcibly displaced as local officials worry about terrorist sleeper cells.

text: VATICAN CITY — Ashes to ashes is fine, the Vatican says, as long as you don’t spread them around.

headline: How Does a Guy Go From Playing Baseball to Killing Men for a Living?
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. How does a reporter collect information for the story of a professional baseball player who became a hit man? He knows a guy ...

headline: White Gold Butchers, From April Bloomfield, Opens Uptown
text: WHITE GOLD BUTCHERS Not long ago, the artisanal local butcher appeared to be going the way of the snow leopard. But a growing demand for alternatives to factory chickens and plastic packages of chuck steaks has inspired a butcher’s renaissance in many places. Now, Upper West Side carnivores can have their pastured beef, air-chilled poultry and heritage pork, along with charcuterie like head cheese, from the new meat market and restaurant that Ken Friedman and the chef April Bloomfield have bestowed on the neighborhood. About half the no-frills corner space is an open kitchen with display cases for the work of Erika Nakamura and Jocelyn Guest, the butchers. Items like rotisserie chicken can be brought home for dinner, but those tempted by a slab of pork terrine or a hot dog on the spot can perch at a counter and even accompany it with beer, wine or kombucha from a tap. Tufted black leather banquettes, tables and chairs furnish the restaurant portion, with counter service at breakfast and lunch, and waiters at dinner with a menu of items like lettuce wrap with crispy pork, hacked chicken with green sauce, smoked lamb ribs, and rice with drippings. (Butcher and takeout open Wednesday, restaurant opens Nov. 1): 375 Amsterdam Avenue (78th Street), whitegoldbutchers.com.

headline: College Is the Goal. Will These Three Teenagers Get There?
text: It’s college application season, and The New York Times is at Topeka High School in Kansas, following seniors as they decide where to apply — and whether college is even the right choice for them. Follow along as we introduce you to students in live Facebook chats, and bring in experts to talk through some major issues for families facing this often confusing process.

headline: Giants Release Josh Brown After Documents Showed Abuse
text: The Giants stood behind kicker Josh Brown for months after the details of his 2015 arrest for domestic violence became public this summer. He remained part of the team even when police documents released last week showed Brown admitting to being abusive to his then-wife. And after John Mara, the Giants’ co-owner, acknowledged that Brown had told the team of the abuse, he still remained on the team with full pay, even though the N.F.L. suspended him.

headline: Colin Powell Says He’ll Vote for Hillary Clinton
text: Colin L. Powell, the Republican former secretary of state, said on Tuesday that he planned to vote for Hillary Clinton for president as he condemned her rival, Donald J. Trump, at an event on Long Island.

headline: College Is the Goal: Will These Teenagers Get There?
text: Is Zac’s contrarian side holding him back? Should Nate choose the Ford dealership or architecture? Will harsh financial reality catch up with TaTy? The Times is following three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college.

headline: Accrediting Colleges
text: To the Editor:

headline: 12 Books to Read in Your 20s
text: There are far more worthy books than any of us will get to read in a lifetime. So you better get cracking in your 20s, at the latest. Below are 12 books earnestly if somewhat arbitrarily recommended. To read them all is to learn about wartime, race in America, growing up feeling like you’re different, how cities are built and lived in, grief, the power of imagination and much more.

headline: Gay American Politician Visits Iran. Secret Agents Are on the Case.
text: Iran’s intelligence minister normally does not find himself on the receiving end of criticism by fellow hard-liners asking how he could possibly have overlooked a visit by a gay state legislator from the United States.

headline: Air Pollution’s Toll on Heart May Begin Early
text: Even healthy young adults may suffer ill effects from air pollution.

headline: Review: In ‘Public Enemy,’ a Noble Whistle-Blower Turns Fanatic
text: Henrik Ibsen pulled off one of theater’s great hairpin turns in “An Enemy of the People.” That play’s titular character, Dr. Thomas Stockmann, starts off as a noble whistle-blower, only to turn into a fanatical crusader who delivers a proto-Ayn Randian aria of elitist contempt for the masses.

headline: Eleuteri, a Vintage Jeweler, Brings Italian Glamour to New York
text: In the modern electoral circus, politicians need pop stars, and pop stars need bling.

headline: Inside Azzedine Alaïa’s Intimate Spring Show
text: Azzedine Alaïa is the ultimate fashion homebody. Whether he wants to throw a dinner or a fashion show, he does it chez Alaïa. That choice is intrinsically tied to the designer’s ideology: one of welcoming and embracing all, the way his signature clingy knits embrace your figure and invite compliments. When Alaïa stages a show, it’s in a space downstairs from his bedroom; when he invites you to a dinner, you eat in his own kitchen, and he treats you with the kind of solicitude that makes you feel not just like a friend, but like family. (When I was overheating at a dinner back in June, Alaïa yanked the power cord of his fridge out of the wall to plug in a fan.)

headline: The Path to College
text: College is the goal. Will these three teenagers get there? Anemona Hartocollis brings you their stories in this Facebook Live series.

headline: Review: ‘Turner,’ a Portrait of a Most Dazzling and Disagreeable Artist
text: The most cloying American artist of the 20th century was almost certainly Thomas Kinkade (1958-2012), whose popular paintings depicted what seemed to be well-lighted houses for elves. His work, as Joan Didion wrote, “typically featured a cottage or a house of such insistent coziness as to seem actually sinister, suggestive of a trap designed to attract Hansel and Gretel.”

headline: Mosul, Heathrow, Quetta: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Review: Rip Van Winkle Meets Creepy Gnomes in ‘Now Is the Time. Now Is the Best Time. Now Is the Best Time of Your Life.’
text: You think clowns are scary? Try gnomes. Five of them are in “Now Is the Time. Now Is the Best Time. Now Is the Best Time of Your Life.,” and they pop up from hidden recesses onstage, staring at the audience from behind bushy beards and plastic facial masks. When they creepily whisper-sing, “Have you seen the ghost of Tom/ Long white bones with the flesh all gone/ Wouldn’t it be chilly with no skin on?” you know Halloween has come early.

headline: Artificial Intelligence as a Bridge for Art and Reality
text: How to get people interested in art? How to engage millennials? How to expose permanent-collection works that sit in storage? These are questions art museums constantly ponder.

headline: ‘We Need to Clean This Up’: Clinton Aide’s Newly Public Email Shows Concern
text: In a March 2015 interview, President Obama said that he had learned about Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server as secretary of state “the same time everybody else learned it, through news reports.”

headline: Buffalo Philharmonic, Once Languishing, Has Come a Long Way
text: BUFFALO — JoAnn Falletta, the music director of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, stood outside Kleinhans Music Hall here at dusk one recent Saturday and pointed to the brick exterior, punctuated by a line of glass blocks.

headline: Voter Attitudes Toward Hillary Clinton
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paul Beatty Wins Man Booker Prize With ‘The Sellout’
text: Paul Beatty’s novel “The Sellout,” a blistering satire about race in America, won the Man Booker Prize on Tuesday, marking the first time an American writer has won the award.

headline: Why a Media Merger That Should Go Through Might Not
text: Opponents of the proposed AT&T purchase of Time Warner don’t want to just block the $85.4 billion deal: They want to overturn decades of antitrust policy and case law.

headline: Is New York Too Expensive for Restaurateurs? We Do the Math
text: The New York City restaurateur’s perennial lament — that staying afloat is tougher here than anywhere else in the country — grows louder each time another restaurant closes. Rents are astronomical, the complaint goes; wages are rising, regulations are byzantine, and don’t even talk about the price of fresh produce.

headline: Review: In ‘Supersonic,’ the Band Oasis and Its Combative Brothers
text: “Don’t look back in anger,” Oasis advises in one of its biggest hits from the 1990s. The ease of accomplishing that depends on just what it is you are looking back on. “Supersonic,” a thoroughly entertaining documentary about that rock band, directed by Mat Whitecross, keeps its view tight and specific, limiting its narrative to the roughly four years between the group’s formation and its spectacular 1996 concerts in Knebworth, England, which drew a total of 250,000 fans over two nights.

headline: Tracing the Path of AIDS Through the Dance World
text: The opening nights of Danspace Project’s “Platform 2016: Lost and Found” stung like a bandage ripped off an open wound. The first programs of the six-week platform, an exploration of the effect AIDS has had on artists, made clear that the trauma this epidemic wreaked on the dance world is far from over.

headline: Review: 500 Years of Cultivation in ‘Portrait of a Garden’
text: The vision of nature being lovingly tended in Rosie Stapel’s documentary, “Portrait of a Garden,” is remarkably evocative. This film’s sensitivity to the weather, the temperature and the changing light and seasons transports you to the Netherlands and the site of a restored, nearly 500-year-old kitchen garden. As you watch its diligent overseers at work, the movie feels like a Zen meditation on time, nature and human activity.

headline: In ‘Rectify,’ Life After Prison and the Chance to Be Reborn
text: For decades, television has been cop, judge, jury and jailer. Police and courtroom dramas are a mainstay; a few series, like “Orange Is the New Black,” have explored prison life. But “Rectify,” a drama entering its final season on SundanceTV on Wednesday, is exceptional in being concerned with what comes after prison, for ex-convicts, for their families, for an entire community.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: A Retort to Shrinking Screens, in an Ultra-Immersive Show at the Whitney
text: When we talk about technology and the movies these days, we’re often talking about the movies becoming smaller. They can be shot on GoPros and cellphones, then watched on laptops, tablets and those same cellphones. Access to the means of production grows while the artistic product shrinks. In the future, the moving image fits in your palm, a tidy, flat display held a few inches from your face.

headline: Public Theater Takes Its Under the Radar Festival to a Warship
text: For the Under the Radar Festival in January, the Public Theater will stage a musical on the hangar deck of a World War II-era aircraft carrier.

headline: A Scene Right Out of Philip Roth: His Books Come Home to Newark’s Library
text: NEWARK — In Philip Roth’s novella “Goodbye, Columbus,” the Newark Public Library is where Neil Klugman spends a summer working with a colleague whose “breath smells of hair oil and hair oil of breath” and mooning over the rich and sexy Brenda Patimkin. In real life, Mr. Roth has designated the library, which he has called his home away from home, as the repository for his own book collection, a bequest that will be announced here on Thursday evening at the inaugural Philip Roth Lecture, to be delivered by Zadie Smith.

headline: Balanchine’s ‘Prodigal Son’ Is Returning to Ballet Theater
text: There are women in all three scenes of George Balanchine’s “Prodigal Son” (1929), but the woman in the central scene is, as they say, something else. In the first and final scenes, the title character is seen with his sisters — a friendly, kind part of the domesticity against which he rebels. When he returns, they’re the first to welcome him. They don’t dance and they don’t wear point shoes.

headline: One Last Growl for F.C.C.’s Sharp-Toothed Watchdog
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama picked Tom Wheeler, a former cable and wireless lobbyist, to head the Federal Communications Commission in 2013, AT&T celebrated the pick as “inspired” and the cable industry said it was “exceptional.”

headline: Cate Blanchett Morphs a Dozen Times in ‘Manifesto’
text: Most people probably wouldn’t rush to read a lot of philosophical declarations by artists from the past century. But if those statements — known historically as manifestoes — were delivered by the actress Cate Blanchett, playing distinctly different characters, audiences might be more likely to pay attention.

headline: We’re Animals, After All
text: In 2012, Victor Wong, a video game designer for a toy company in Toronto, had a tiny midlife crisis in his hotel room while on vacation. He felt burned out on work but was strangely revived by sniffing the hotel toiletries, which came from a niche fragrance line he can no longer recall.
